DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR W. T. ARTHUR

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pay a brief tribute to the late Bill Arthur. He was one of the kindest, most unselfish , caring and happy persons that it has ever been my privilege to know. During an association of over 16 years I never heard him speak ill of anyone, betray a confidence or behave in any way other than with honour and decency. He was a man whom it is difficult to contemplate having an enemy. On the other hand, it is well known that the number of his friends was legion. As one of them I deeply regret the way in which he met his death and that he is no longer with us. I send my condolences to the surviving relatives of this fine, decent man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew Bill Arthur over the whole of the post-war years. He enlisted in the Australian Military Forces in August 1940, became a bombardier in the following year and a sergeant in 1942, transferred to the Australian Imperial Force in 1942, was commissioned and served in New Guinea and Borneo and was transferred to the Reserve of Officers in September 1946. He was active on the Liberal side of politics over the next few decades. He was a candidate for the Federal seat of Barton and, indeed, was elected to the House of Representatives for the electorate of Barton at the general election of 1966. He served on a number of committees inside the Parliament. He was very friendly in his approach, was regarded by all as a friend and made a contribution to this Parliament. One can only regret that he has died and particularly regret the tragic circumstances of his death. The Government joins with Senator Chipp in extending to his relatives deep sympathy.

—I knew the late Bill Arthur for a number of years, long before he or I entered Parliament, although we were active in politics in different ways. In fact, I was the Secretary of the Barton Federal Electorate Council of the Australian Labor Party in 1954 and in 1955 when he stood as the Liberal Party candidate for the seat of Barton against the then Leader of the Opposition, the Right Honourable Dr Evatt. He offered himself as a Liberal candidate not only then but also in 1958 and, I think, in 1961. He eventually won the seat in 1966 and held it for one term. In that period he was my local member. He was a good member, and I always got on well with him. All members of the Australian Labor Party within the Barton Federal electorate express their deepest sympathy to the late Mr Arthur's relatives.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Personally and on behalf of the National Country Party I support the expressions of sympathy that have been made in this chamber this afternoon to the relatives of the late Bill Arthur. I did not know Bill Arthur when he was a member of this Parliament but I certainly knew him for many years. I found him to be a man of friendly and energetic disposition. We sadly regret not only his death but also the extremely unfortunate circumstances of his death. I want to add to and endorse the expressions that have been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for National Development and Energy say last Thursday, 4 March, that a fall in international oil prices would mean a fall in Australian oil prices? Since then has the Prime Minister said that he doubts whether 'any good purpose would be served by a price reduction'? Will the Minister clear up this apparent conflict between himself and the Prime Minister and inform the Senate how Australian petrol prices are to be fixed in the future , having regard to the matters of fact referred to?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I made a number of statements simply restating what has been and is the policy of the Government in fixing the price of oil in Australia, which is determined on the basis of import parity pricing. I indicated that, in line with the International Energy Agency's view that all oil in all countries should be priced at world scarcity prices, we in Australia had chosen the price of Saudi light crude as the price for Australia. That happened to be one of the cheaper prices in the world and Saudi Arabia also happened to be the main source of Australian oil. I indicated that it had been our practice since then, on 1 July and 1 January of each year, to review what had happened in the previous six months and to adjust the price in terms of the movement in the price of Saudi light crude in American dollars. So there would be an adjustment in terms of the movement in the price and in the exchange rate as it applied between America and Australia. The answer is yes. I indicated that on a number of occasions last week.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has commented but has not in any way altered the text of what I have said. Indeed he reiterates the basis of what I have said. When interviewed by the local Press in Roma-I have the text here-he was asked:
Are we going to see reductions in fuel prices . . .
The Prime Minister said:

Well, the prices that we have been paying up to this point haven't come down. We don't know what is going to happen. The British have brought down their North Sea price. The Government would have to make a decision about that, but there is no doubt that the general trend over time that oil prices is going to be upwards , and whether any good purpose will be served by an actual reduction in Australia that is a question the Government will have to look at.

He quite clearly meant by that statement that, although for a time a surplus will be created in the world by a number of factors in which Australia has co- operated, in the longer term there will be a reversion to scarcity and higher prices. Of course the pressure on scarcity has caused Australia and other countries to move to alternative policies. In no way has the Prime Minister in that statement come into conflict either with the Government's policy or with statements which I have made. At this moment nobody knows what will be the movements of world prices. The Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets on 19 March to determine its policies. It will have to look at policies in two ways: First of all, to reduce the volume-that will be a determination by Saudi Arabia largely as to how far it can drop its volume-and, secondly, whether Saudi Arabia will lower its price. If prices fall particularly low a number of OPEC countries will find themselves in grave economic difficulties. Indeed, they could find themselves in a destabilised condition. I point out that, whilst there is some alleviation in price at the moment, in the long term an orderly approach to pricing will be the best thing for the world at large.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate . I preface my question by saying that I commend the governments of Australia and New Zealand for their quick and humane action in already rendering assistance to Tonga which suffered such tremendous cyclone damage last week. Is the Minister aware that 45,000 people in Tonga are now homeless, that there is virtually no fresh water available now and no roofing to catch fresh water, that in fact a serious water pollution crisis has developed owing to the escape of raw sewage into the ground water and that an extremely serious food shortage will strike the islands in about two weeks time? In view of this disastrous situation, will the Government encourage a community response from the people of Australia to alleviate the plight of the people of Tonga, in addition to the generous response already announced by his Government? From past experience would the Minister agree that Australian people respond magnificently to people in times of distress? Would he therefore request the Prime Minister, if thought practicable, to invite all political parties to request nation-wide participation of the Australian people in assisting the poor and distressed people of Tonga?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The plight of the people of Tonga is in fact a very serious one, as Senator Chipp has indicated. Cyclone Isaac, as it was called, hit the three main islands of Tonga on 3 March and, as he described, caused considerable devastation. Whilst casualties fortunately appear to have been few, the hurricane has given rise to an immediate and very serious need for humanitarian assistance. It has also caused long term economic difficulties in what is a small island kingdom.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government was pleased to be able to respond promptly, as Senator Chipp indicated, and positively to requests from the Tongan Government for assistance in relieving the hardships which its people now face. The Aid Bureau of the Department of Foreign Affairs, in conjunction with the Department of Defence, as he knows, arranged a number of Royal Australian Air Force Hercules flights which have carried urgently needed supplies of food, shelter, material, communications equipment and other equipment and medicines to Tonga. In addition a contingent of Australian Army engineers, comprising some 70 officers and men, is helping to assess the damage and re-establish services. I sketch this against the background of Senator Chipp's further request. Two RAAF helicopters to assist in re-establishing inter-island communication and the distribution of supplies to the outer islands have also been provided. We have co-operated closely with other countries, particularly New Zealand. In conjunction with the Government of Tonga we are now assessing the most effective ways in which we can continue to meet Tonga's immediate emergency relief and longer term rehabilitation needs. Honourable senators may be assured that we will continue to do that.

On the question of the community response-I take note of it-the Government is actively encouraging the provision of assistance by private individuals and organisations. Honourable senators will be aware that the International Disaster Emergency Committee Appeal for Tonga was launched yesterday. Indeed, the Government urges the people of Australia to give the appeal full support. The Government hopes that the Committee's appeal will be met with wholehearted support throughout the Australian community. So what Senator Chipp is seeking has already been done. If there are aspects that I have not covered I will draw the Prime Minister's attention to them.

—My question is directed to Senator Baume in his capacities as Minister representing the Minister for Health and Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. The question relates to the police raids on Dr Wainer's Fertility Control Clinic in Melbourne on 19 February. Is it normal practice, as was claimed by a spokesman from the Department of Health as reported in the Age on 27 February, to advise doctors of mistakes or possible mistakes in the itemising of services rendered at least once before taking any police action against them? Further, is it the case, as appears from the information sworn out in support of the search warrant in this matter on 18 February, that the Department knew of a possible inaccuracy in the billing of certain ultrasound scanning procedures by the clinic as early as May 1981, and certainly by June 1981, and yet took no action whatsoever in this respect until the police raids in February this year? Is it further the case that it is not uncommon for itemising errors to be made as a result of honest and reasonable mistake, given the thousands of items on the fee schedule and the close similarity and description of many of the procedures in question, and that that is the reason for the existence of the advance warning and counselling system that currently applies? If the answer to all those questions is yes, why was not the normal practice followed in this case?

—It would clearly be proper to go back to the Minister whom I represent to get detailed answers to the particular questions as to matters of fact, for example. Before I acknowledge that a normal procedure was not followed , I would like to have that checked. I think all honourable senators would agree -I am not now referring to Dr Wainer or to anyone else-that medical fraud, wherever it exists, requires to be treated with the utmost seriousness and with the utmost diligence. It is also correct for Senator Evans to say that it is normal for counselling to take place where genuine errors are thought to have occurred and that police action is generally a second step. It is true that itemising errors can be made in good faith. Having said that, I would not want to see Dr Wainer or anyone else treated unfairly or improperly. I will undertake to have the particular matters referred to Mr Newman to obtain particular responses.

Based on the information that I have with regard to the Tasmanian projects, I understand that the decision not to continue funding some projects was made only after careful consideration of information and advice received from the State CYSS committee. The Department considered this and, after consultation with local members of parliament, the decision was taken. I understand that the CYSS committee in Tasmania prepared recommendations on projects in three groups: Firstly, those it considered viable; secondly, those with particular problems which give doubts about their viability but which the committee considered should be given sufficient time to overcome their problems; and thirdly, those with particular problems largely related to low levels of youth unemployment and low participation. The continued viability of some projects was considered to be in doubt and the four projects which were closed in Tasmania fell into the third category which I mentioned. There was never any suggestion that the State committee, in making those recommendations, was showing any bias against country projects. I understand that every project in Tasmania received the same consideration by the committee. However, I have noted the suggestion in the question from Senator Coates. I undertake to refer it to the Minister for his consideration.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that many pensioners in Victorian country areas are without convenient access to local public hospitals? Is it a fact that in Victoria the Bush Nursing hospitals charge fees to pensioners? Are pensioners in areas serviced only by Bush Nursing hospitals obliged to take out hospital insurance if they wish to be hospitalised in a place where they are reasonably accessible to friends and relatives? —I am aware that Senator Hamer is seeking to obtain the maximum benefit for some of the people in remote areas of Victoria. I point out that the same problems apply in other States but Senator Hamer has drawn particular attention to the situation in his own State. My understanding is that the hospitals to which he referred-the hospitals operated by the Bush Nurses-are not public hospitals in the legal sense. Therefore, they do not have access to some of the privileges which public hospitals attract. He therefore points out that some pensioners in Victoria may suffer disability because of this and because there is no access to other facilities. He asks whether we will undertake to include this matter in any review that is undertaken of hospital arrangements. I will certainly pass this request on to the Minister for Health. I hope that he will examine it favourably. The Minister for Health, like Senator Hamer, is sympathetic towards the needs of pensioners in Victoria and other places. He would want to provide for their maximum benefit in everything he did.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Is it normal practice for Telecom Australia subscribers on Great Barrier Reef island resorts to have to pay in advance for the installation of radio-telephone facilities to those islands from the mainland? Is it a fact that the Minister for Communications chaired a meeting between Telecom and a Mr Keith Williams, the developer of a new resort at Hamilton Island, off Proserpine, at which a decision was made that Telecom would install a 60-channel radio-telephone initially, followed by a 350-channel radio- telephone with no advance payment being made by Mr Williams?

—I must confess to the Senate that I have never visited a Barrier Reef resort island-I hope to remedy that one day-much less had the opportunity to examine in detail the arrangements which apply to the installation of telephones. Are there any other State governments which have likewise failed to apply the terms of the Whale Protection Act to the territorial waters within their jurisdiction? What action is the Commonwealth taking to secure the full implementation of this legislation in all Australian waters and seas?

—I am aware that discussions have been held by the Commonwealth with the State and the Northern Territory governments regarding the need for complementary whale protection legislation to apply in State and Northern Territory waters. The New South Wales Government has indicated that amendments to its National Parks and Wildlife Act are not strictly necessary to give effect to this intention. It says that it is prepared to give consideration to introducing the legislation, but there is no indication as to when this might be or whether in fact it is going to occur. The Victorian Government has indicated that it favours the option of amending the Victorian Wildlife Act 1975 so that it will complement the Commonwealth Whale Protection Act 1980.
—It has done so.

—I note that Senator Missen, by interjection, said that the Victorian Government has in fact done so. So there is quite a difference between the approach of the Victorian Government and that of its socialist counterpart in New South Wales. However, I can say that all States have indicated support for the Commonwealth legislation and have indicated their intention of co- operating in the implementation of a complementary regime of whale protection. —Can the Minister for National Development and Energy confirm that the submission by his Department to the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania argued that demand for power in Tasmania could be met comfortably from sources already established, thereby circumventing the need for the proposed Gordon-below-Franklin scheme? Is the Minister of the view that this opinion stands and has merit? If this opinion of the experts in the Minister's Department is supported by him, will he take the necessary steps to ensure that the Federal Government officially conveys these views to the Tasmanian Parliament before it debates the proposed scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be a very over-simplistic precis of what the submission in fact said. The submission indicated that the Department had revised downwards its previous estimate of the needs of Tasmania at the time. It did so because a number of enterprises which had been foreshadowed are not going to take place. On the other hand, it has no way of knowing at all whether, when the recessive tendencies of this world disperse in the months and years ahead, there will be in fact new enterprises of a particular nature. All it could do was to indicate that, based upon the present situation and the present expectation of industries and development, it had lowered its estimate of the capacity. But it made the point that any assumption of demands for electricity must take into account an estimate of the future development of Tasmania. That is not a judgment that the department can make. I take it that it is a political judgment for Tasmania. Therefore, the submission itself does not conclude that there is no need for any extra power, whether hydro or thermal. It simply states the reason why it has lowered its estimates for the time being. It may well be that in a year's time, if the demands emerge around Tasmania, it will upgrade its estimates.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment: Has the Federal Government any plans and commitments to become involved in the Australian Year of the Tree which is aimed at focusing the public's attention on the need to protect and preserve Australian forests? If so , what are these commitments?

—I am very interested in Senator Watson's reference to the Australian Year of the Tree. I will have to refer the question to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to find the particular answer to the question he asked. —I ask the Minister for Finance: Has a new position been created in the Department of Primary Industry for Mr Al Wallace, the former First Assistant Secretary in charge of the dairy division? Does the creation of this new position, described as 'principal adviser', fall within the Department of Finance's general guidelines on expenditure restraint issued last month? —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When the Minister approaches the Department of Primary Industry to seek any information that is available will she determine whether Mr Wallace's duties will involve anything other than keeping his mouth shut about what he knows on breaches of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade by the Australian Dairy Corporation and the subsequent sanitising of the DPI files?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have nothing further to add.

—I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: What is the Government's attitude to statements made by senior public servants concerning policy matters, particularly those which are outside their spheres of responsibility?

—I take it that the honourable senator is referring to public statements which have been made by Mr Perkins. Mr Perkins, at the moment, is not a public servant. He is, in fact, a statutory office holder. I think people should understand the difference in regulations which apply to a person and also in the limitation on what he says. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it the Australian Government's assessment that this week Israel will invade the Lebanon and if it does not do so this week, it will do so next week or in the remaining six weeks to 25 April? Is it true that this invasion will have the support of the United States of America? What steps is Australia taking to deter these ominous threats of yet wider military entanglements in the Middle East?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Teague asked some fairly specific questions and I will refer those to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Communications noted an item in the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 March which alleges 'Telecom leads world in profit' and that Telecom's net profits and its charges for comparable systems are among the world's highest? This claim has been made by a group named the Australian Telecommunications Users Group. Can the Minister inform the Senate first whether the alleged facts are correct and, secondly, who are the members of this group?

—Although I have seen the article to which the honourable senator refers, I am not aware of the details as to the group of people nor can I give him the assurance he seeks that each of the facts set out in detail is correct. I think it will be more appropriate if I take the article, have the facts and the group checked and come back to the honourable senator with the extra information he is seeking.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security: What would be the cost to the Government if the amount of income a person receiving the age pension was able to earn before losing his pension entitlement were increased to equal the pension itself? Can the Minister specify the cost on the basis of the number of eligible pensioners at present and the number of persons who might be eligible if the pension criteria were changed to include this provision? Can the Minister also supply details of the calculations made to answer this question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information on the matter raised by the honourable senator. The question he asked mainly involved allowing an income test free area equal to the pension itself. The cost of increasing the free area of income to that level is estimated to be about $165m in a full year for existing age pensioners. That estimate is a gross cost because, of course, some taxation revenue would flow from such an increase in pensions as all pension payments are taxable for pensioners above the taxable limit. If this were done the income limit at November 1981 rates for the payment of pension would increase from $159 .40 to $209.10 a week for a single person. In other words, a part pension would be payable from the income limit to a total income level of $209 a week. For a married couple the peak income at which a part pension would be payable would be $348.60 a week.

ANSWER.PARA: This increase would mean that new pensioners would come on to the roll. People who currently are beyond the income range for the pension would be admitted to a part pension. There is no up to date comprehensive income data which would enable me to give the Senate an estimate of the cost of adding those pensioners to the pension roll. The cost estimate I gave was based on the reported incomes of current age pensioners in December 1981. At least 325,000 pensioners could be expected to gain. It is assumed that pensioners aged 70 years or more who have not stated their incomes, of whom there are about 126,000, would not be affected by the proposal. This could mean that the cost is underestimated. There are a number of uncertainties in the figures I have given to the Senate as I do not have figures which would enable me to state a precise cost in answer to the question which has been asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of the 12-point program for the advancement of women announced yesterday by the Government of France to mark International Women's Day? Will the Government undertake to examine the French initiatives, which are reported to include increased family allowances and pensions for women, laws to promote equality and to prohibit sex discrimination, reform of the laws on alimony and common property and reform of discriminatory tax laws? Is the Government prepared to make a commitment to Australian women similar to the commitment made to French women by the Government of France?

—I noted some of the Press comment yesterday about activities which took place in many places and which featured women. Although I am not aware of the 12-point program set out by the Government of France, I will undertake to ask my colleague the questions put by the honourable senator. I imagine that the Minister will have access to the details but if the honourable senator has access to documents it might be helpful for her to give them to me and I will ensure that they are passed on as well.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the Government aware that a former United States intelligence operative, Mr Edwin P. Wilson, a man who is wanted in the United States for selling arms and intelligence equipment and information to Libya, was in Melbourne in January 1976 when he was working for the United States naval intelligence group known as Task Force 157? Has the Government any information about links between Mr Wilson and the two Australian intelligence agencies, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Australian Secret Intelligence Service? What steps has the Government taken to ensure that Mr Wilson has no continuing relationship or contact with members of Australian intelligence for his international rent-a-spy organisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of Senator Bolkus's question, I personally have no information of the existence of the gentleman or whether he, existing, was in Melbourne as stated in 1976 or whether he is or was, as Senator Bolkus has stated, a particular intelligence agent. I will refer that matter to the responsible Minister. The second matter really concerns my colleague the Attorney-General because it is in regard to whether any person had any links with ASIO or ASIS. I think I would be right in saying that the Government, as with all governments, would take the attitude that this is not a matter it makes comments on. I will refer the question to the appropriate Minister for study and any future comment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED KINGDOM: HOSPITAL CHARGES FOR VISITORS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. By way of preface I refer to the recent decision of the British Government to cease the free health coverage available to visitors to Great Britain. In view of the fact that European Economic Community countries, Warsaw Pact countries plus Romania, Yugoslavia, New Zealand and Malta have all made what I might call knock for knock hospital coverage arrangements, is it due to Australia's bondage to private health schemes that we cannot do the same?

—The question asked by the honourable senator really involves a matter of policy which will have to be referred to the Minister for Health. It may require Government consideration. I will undertake to pass it on to Mr MacKellar for such consideration as he can give it.

—I ask a supplementary question. I know the Minister is not like Senator Withers and that he does read newspapers. Would he look at the London Guardian of the appropriate date? I will hand a copy of that paper to him . It elucidates the matter much better than I can and rams home the fact that private health funds are obviously denying us a right which virtually all other nationals will have when they go to the United Kingdom.
—If Senator Mulvihill is prepared to give me a copy of the London Guardian I will read it with pleasure.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport by stating that local government is mounting a major campaign for increased road funds on the following grounds: Firstly, the Australian road system has deteriorated to an alarming extent; secondly, insufficient funds are being allocated for roads by the Commonwealth Government; thirdly, States and local government are carrying an unfair share of the burden of cost. As transport is very important to people in the urban community and in the country, what does the Minister intend to do about this funding inadequacy?

—I think all honourable senators would be aware of the campaign being undertaken in this regard by local government and would have received representations from various organisations in their own States from time to time . Presently the Commonwealth is committed to the provision of grants totalling $ 3,650m to the States and the Northern Territory for roads over the five years from 1980-81 to 1984-85. This very substantial Commonwealth commitment, in the light of public expenditure restraints imposed as a result of its anti- inflationary budgetary strategy, in the circumstances does seem to be as much as can be possibly done to enhance the development of the Australian road system at the moment. In 1981-82, $685m has been appropriated by the Roads Grants Act 1981 . This represents an increase of 9 per cent when compared with the $628m provided by the Commonwealth last year. All States and the Northern Territory have been allocated a uniform 9 per cent increase in their grants in this current financial year. Of course, the Minister is aware of these concerns expressed in the community and shortly will be introducing legislation in the House to appropriate the levels of funds which the Government has undertaken to provide over the remaining three years of the current roads programs.

—I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs: In what way is the ability of officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs to provide a service to veterans in Queensland's rural areas being affected by financial restrictions , especially restrictions on travel within the Department?

—No complaints have been brought to my attention in connection with any restraints that have been imposed on staff members of my Department travelling in Queensland and any difficulties that those restraints may be creating throughout outback Queensland. I would be grateful if Senator Colston would bring to my attention any specific complaints which I would be able to investigate and then bring down an early reply for him.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce by drawing his attention to a report several weeks ago that about 30,000 workers in the Ford Motor Car Co. of Australia and General Motors-Holden's Ltd are to get a shorter working week. Can the Minister say whether a date has been set for the commencement of the shorter working week and what is the cost to the industry of this commitment? Finally, does the car manufacturing industry need the protection we give it if it can afford to give its employees shorter working hours?

—Senator Walters has asked for a deal of detailed information on arrangements with respect to the Ford and General Motors workers which I do not have. Hence I will have to seek from the Minister for Industry and Commerce the information which she has sought. However, she concluded her question with the general observation that the shorter working week could demonstrate that high protection was not necessary. It certainly is true that the shorter working week , by pushing up the unit cost of labour, renders any industry affected less competitive and undoubtedly gives rise to a desire for a higher level of protection; indeed, often it causes a demand for a higher level of protection. However, the simple fact of the matter is that the more the cost of labour is inflated the more difficult it will be for the Government to ensure that we have a country in which employment creation continues. I think all sections of the community, be they trade unions or employers, have a vested interest in maintaining the cost of labour in Australia at a fairly competitive level. The caution which is contained in the question from the honourable senator is worthy and should be borne in mind by both employers and employees.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General. The High Court judgment handed down on 28 October 1981 in the case of Shaddock & Associates v. the Parramatta City Council in the matter of civil liability for economic or financial loss suffered as a result of negligent advice may raise considerable problems across the entire ambit of giving advice, be those involved business advisers, farm advisers, health centre sisters, or anyone in between. Is it considered that under this precedent members of parliament could be found against by the courts in their business of supplying advice and information from the best sources at their disposal? Is it likely that advice will now be much harder to obtain? Is there any consideration of legislation being introduced that may grant any preclusions to any group or groups of people that may now be deemed to be liable as a result of having given what might be judged to be negligent advice?

—I am, of course, well aware of the High Court decision to which Senator Archer refers. I suppose I should say that I do not give any legal advice or legal opinions. I can say that in this situation I cannot see any reason why the duty of care laid down by the High Court in that case would not be cast upon members of parliament to the same extent that it may be cast upon other members of the community. I think it is wise that members of parliament should be aware of the decision, if they place themselves in any position of giving advice. The circumstances of any case and the course that should be followed are matters for them to decide on private legal advice. I am not in the business of providing that, as all honourable senators know.
—Are you saying that the criteria in Shaddock's case are applicable to members and their staff? Are you really saying that?

—I simply say that the general duty of care that the High Court has expounded may well, in certain circumstances, apply to members of parliament if they place themselves in a position in which they may come within the principles laid down in that case. That is all I am saying. Members of parliament should be a little careful.
—Would you ever be--

—Answering a question is not the time to be cross-examined by Senator Evans on this subject. If he wants to give his views on what the High Court decision is applying to members of parliament, no doubt they will be very happy to hear his views on the subject. I suggest that he take some opportunity of giving them. Of course, the question of liability is in the realm of the law of negligence. That criterion would have to be satisfied. Other circumstances laid down in the case would have to be satisfied. In general answer to Senator Archer's question, I am saying that it may well be that the general duty of care laid down in that case may in certain circumstances be applicable to members of parliament as it is to everyone else in the community.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that since the beginning of nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll some 15 years ago there have been 41 atmospheric and 47 underground or underwater tests at that site? Will the Minister agree that the French Polynesians have become involuntary guinea pigs and should no longer be exposed to nuclear pollution of any kind? Is the Minister aware of a recent Press report which stated that France is planning to switch its underground nuclear tests at Mururoa to a nearby atoll? Will the Australian Government strongly condemn France's decision to continue testing in the Mururoa region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It should be understood, and I think it has been stated on a number of occasions, that Australia is opposed to France's continued nuclear testing in the South Pacific. This opposition has been frequently stated, both in bilateral talks with the French Government and in multilateral forums such as the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne last October. It is not the Australian Government's practice to lodge a protest with the country concerned whenever a nuclear weapons state carries out an underground explosion. Since 1975 all the French tests at Mururoa Atoll have been conducted under ground. The Government does, however, make formal approaches to the country concerned whenever an atmospheric nuclear test is carried out. The last such approach was to China in 1980. Australia has long been committed to the conclusion of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty which would bring about an end to nuclear testing by all states in all environments. Such a treaty would clearly increase international pressure for an end to all testing and leave those states which continued to test in an isolated and exposed position.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to inquiries by the Australian Embassy in Paris, the French authorities have denied the reports of structural damage and have stated that the radiation situation at the atoll is fully under control. The French response was the subject of a news release issued by the Department of Foreign Affairs on 18 December last year. I know that the Foreign Minister is aware of unsubstantiated reports that France proposes to move its nuclear test site to Kerguelen Island in the southern Indian Ocean. The Minister has seen no evidence to confirm these reports and the French Government has declined to comment on them. If other matters were raised by Senator McIntosh I will refer them to the Foreign Minister for a response from him, but I give that general background to Australia's attitude on this matter so that the Senate may again be informed of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question I asked was not referring to Kerguelen Island. It is obvious that the Minister had a briefing on that matter and was able to get the answer off pat. I was referring to a recent Press statement which said that France was considering shifting its tests to a nearby atoll in the Mururoa region. It is that specific question I was concerned about and whether the Government would continue to object to nuclear testing at any other atoll in the Mururoa region.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have nothing to add to the last part of the answer that I gave to Senator McIntosh's question. As I said, if the Foreign Minister's response provides further information on any specific matters raised by Senator McIntosh I will see that the honourable senator is advised.

—Earlier Senator Watson asked me a question about the Year of the Tree. I am now advised that 1982 has been declared the Year of the Tree in Australia by the United Nations Association of Australia. I understand that the Year will commence on 5 June which is commemorated as World Environment Day .
—It is the Year of the Dog in China.

—I say to the honourable senator that I did not ask the question; I am just supplying the answer. The Year of the Tree is also associated with the launching of the Greening of Australia movement. The Government applauds these initiatives as most important conservation issues.

—During Question Time I was asked a question about the level of profits of Telecom Australia. Whilst I promised to get some information for Senator Lajovic I failed to answer part of his question. I can advise him that all the profit earned by Telecom is ploughed back into the capital expenditure for the telecommunications system and that, expressed as a rate of return on assets employed, the profit represents less than 3 per cent. It grew by 10 per cent in the last year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 25 February Senator Mulvihill asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs a question concerning the situation of Mr John Fraser, an Australian citizen in Zimbabwe. Mr Fraser had been compelled to leave Zimbabwe and his Zimbabwean family because of the Zimbabwean Government's immigration policy as it affected the residence status of foreign husbands. In replying to Senator Mulvihill's question I said that there appeared little that the Australian Government could do, but undertook to find out whether an approach had been made to the Zimbabwean Government on this case. I am pleased to be able to advise that the Government of Zimbabwe has revised its policy governing residence permits for foreign husbands. On 3 March the Zimbabwean Minister of Home Affairs announced that the foreign husbands of Zimbabwean women will be granted time-restricted conditional residence permits when they return to Zimbabwe provided that they can satisfy the Immigrants' Control Board that they are of good character and have no criminal records. The Minister of Home Affairs in Zimbabwe made it clear that the new arrangement will apply to husbands who have previously been refused residence permits and who wish to rejoin their wives in Zimbabwe. I am sure that senators will welcome the flexibility demonstrated by the Government of Zimbabwe in responding to the domestic and international reaction to its earlier policy. A problem which used to confront families like the Frasers has now been removed, and the Zimbabwean goal of building a multi-racial society has been advanced.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Bolkus proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continual failure of the Prime Minister and the coalition government to honour the promises made to the people of Australia as outlined in their 1980 policy speech.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The record of this Government during the past six years is, indeed, a sorry one. It is in many ways the sorriest record of any government in the history of Australian Federation. It is a record which is littered with parliamentary and ministerial excess, deceit, trickery, thuggery and evasion. It is not the record of a government which deserves respect and support from the Australian electorate. The fundamental reason for this is the manner in which the Government has time and time again given its word, given its promise on just about every issue and time and time again disregarded its commitment. From the moment this Government barged into power, scattering the Constitution, it has broken promise after promise. It has, through election policy, through ministerial statements, through speeches, through Budgets and in just about every other public forum made what seemed to be unequivocal commitments and then proceeded to reverse them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is, therefore, proper that at this stage the record of this Government should come under close scrutiny for it was to the people of Australia to whom these promises were made and it was the people of Australia who have entrusted the administration of this country to the Liberal-National Country Party coalition. It is the people of Australia who have not just once, not twice but hundreds of times had that trust betrayed. This Government has blatantly and deliberately betrayed the trust of the Australian people. On this issue alone, I submit, it should stand condemned. As I said earlier, this Government does not deserve the respect of the people of Australia or their support. It does not, as I mentioned, because of the scandalous way in which it has on three occasions used the method of the mugger and the confidence trickster to grab power. It has juggled figures and come up with so-called tax cuts which never really materialise for the average Australian. We all remember full well the advertising before the last federal election which talked of a fistful of dollars; what we were not told then was that the dollars were being taken away, not given to us. The Government has promised not to cut services and programs essential to the welfare of Australians and has done just that with scant regard to those in need or those who have a basic right to the provision of these services.

Let us begin with taxation, the area in which this Government has probably told more lies than any other, the area in which this Government has time and time again gone to the electorate with promises. In fact, this Government has surpassed the world's great magicians by making tax cuts disappear before the very eyes of the taxpayer. During the 1980 election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made a number of statements about taxation. The promises can be summed up when he said:

The Government will maintain its declared taxation objectives: to keep taxes at the lowest level possible compatible with responsible economic management and community needs, to distribute the tax burden as fairly as possible, with particular concern for low income families; and to provide incentives for initiative and enterprise.

That is what he said. In doing so, he repeated a tired old theme which has been issued by this man and his former lackeys, former Treasurer Lynch and present Treasurer Howard. The promise in essence was that this Government would keep taxes at the lowest level possible.

Let us just look at the record. Taxes presently are at a record high. In the last year of the Whitlam Government-in the last Hayden Budget-total Commonwealth tax receipts as a proportion of gross domestic product stood at 23.3 per cent. In the last financial year of the Fraser-Howard economic approach this had risen to 25 per cent. The estimate for the current financial year is 25.5 per cent. If the same ratio operated in this current financial year as operated in the year of the last Hayden budget then every taxpayer in Australia would be paying $13. 60 a week less in tax. The burden has fallen upon the wage and salary earners of this country, those who pay taxes as they earn money through hard work. In the years from 1975-76 to 1980-81 the wages, salaries and supplements of ordinary pay-as-you-earn tax payers rose by 72 per cent. In the same period the money collected under PAYE taxes grew by over 100 per cent. This can be contrasted with the position of those people who are non-PAYE taxpayers; their incomes rose by 94 per cent while their tax burden increased by 56.6 per cent-almost half the increase of PAYE taxpayers. Are these the fair and equitable tax arrangements that the Prime Minister talks about? Is this the work of the low tax party? Is this compatible with community needs?

The Prime Minister said also during the election campaign that the Government would have particular concern for low income families. This is an outrageous untruth coming from a government which has done more than any other to drive a wedge between the haves and the have-nots and to make the poor poorer and the rich richer. One has to draw out only one example to show this. A person earning $9,500 a year at the moment would, given the assumed increases in wages over the last five years, have been earning $5,000 a year in 1975-76. The additional tax payable by that person this financial year compared with his 1975-76 tax is an extra $404 or almost $8 a week. Meanwhile, however, a person earning $95,000 a year now-somewhere close to the salary of the Prime Minister and his ministerial colleagues-on the same salary increase assumption would have been earning $50, 000 a year in 1975-76. Under this Government this person's tax would have decreased by an astounding $2,537 per annum in that period, almost $50 less tax a week. That is how the Government has adjusted tax scales to benefit those most in need. That is how the Government has paid particular concern to the low income earners. It has paid them no attention at all in a positive sense.

The Government's taxation promises are, in fact, hollow just as its promises to provide incentives for initiative and enterprise are hollow. The only incentives provided by this Government are those aimed at big business. Small business has suffered intolerable pressure from this Government, pressure so intolerable that in the last financal year we saw almost 5,000 bankruptcies involving small businesses in this country. Almost 5,000 firms went to the wall not able to sustain the economic policies of this Government, policies which through record high interest rates and scarcity of money supply made it impossible for small business to borrow in an attempt to compete, to expand or to hire more staff. At the last election the Government's promises on taxation were just empty rhetoric . We had promises of full tax indexation which never eventuated in any realistic sense for any realistic period. The promises about repaying increases in the crude oil levy, which the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) knows about, and the promise to repay those increases by way of tax cuts or increased family allowances are other promises not yet kept. Throughout his term as Prime Minister, Mr Fraser has harped on sound economic management. In September 1980 he told the Australian people that the domestic deficit would be wiped out altogether. But where is the talk now of wiping out the domestic deficit, with an expected overrun in the Budget deficit of at least $1,300m-a figure that we are not sure of because the Government itself is unclear as to its extent?

This Government has, in fact, been pinning its whole strategy on economic performance-the promises of wiping out Budget deficits, full employment, economic growth and lower inflation; but nothing of the kind has happened. The Prime Minister parades as a tower of strength while his policies are falling all around him. Inflation is now just as high as it was when six years ago Fraser assumed office, and it is going even higher. Nothing has been done to combat unemployment-the unemployed being the fodder in the fight against inflation. Policies used by this Government have simply and consciously made matters worse. Unemployment-using the official number of jobless-stands at almost 450,000 with the expectation that it will climb to half a million. Six per cent of the work force is officially unemployed and unofficially the figure stands at almost twice that. In the area of economic growth-something for which this Government professes to stand-the record is appalling in that, as one of the richest countries in the world, we have no growth and in fact we are going into reverse. The Government's record is one of broken promise after broken promise and it goes on and on.

In regard to education, the Government has for six years talked about maintaining real levels of spending. It has talked about providing services and resources in the areas of greatest need. In 1977 Prime Minister Fraser talked about helping the isolated and handicapped children, Aboriginal children and unemployed youth. These promises are in tatters. Those who are really in need of equal educational opportunities have been tossed on to the social scrap heap. Spending on Aboriginal education has been cut by more than 30 per cent since 1975. Expenditure on isolated children's allowances has been cut by more than $ 5m in real terms and handicapped children's allowances were not increased between 1976 and 1980. As a consequence they have been substantially cut in real terms. In the area of unemployed youth the Government's record is pitiful. The Fraser Government slashed programs for training and retraining. It has given token funding increases for the Education Program for Unemployed Youth and the school to work transition program is just not working.
In the area of health we need only begin with the famous statement made by the Prime Minister in 1975 when he said:
We will maintain Medibank, and ensure that the standard of health care does not decline.

Since then we have gone through six tortuous changes to the health system, all brought about by enormous pressure from private medical funds and resulting in two things-higher health charges for all Australians and a decline in standards. What sort of standard of health care is it when the system is so shabbily organised and presided over that doctors are able to defraud the system of, at the lowest estimate, $1,000m a year? Community health care programs have been disregarded by this Government. Spending on such schemes as a proportion of the health budget is well down on 1975 levels. We have no Medibank in the true, original sense of the word and fewer and fewer people, because of exorbitant doctors' and health insurance fees, have access to adequate health care.

One other area which this Government has ballyhooed about time and time again is that of ministerial responsibility, although one must admit that, with the recent activities, indiscretions, dealings and extra-parliamentary indulgences of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), the Government has gone somewhat quiet in this area in recent days. But let us look at the promise and the performance in this area. In March 1978 the Prime Minister, in an electorate broadcast, said:

My Government has demonstrated again and again our fundamental commitment to restoring integrity to public administration in Australia. Our record in this regard is without parallel in our history. As long as I lead the Government, there is no way known that anything less than the highest code and practice of public administration will be tolerated.

I challenge the Government and the Leader of the Government to affirm this statement here today. Just when the Government was getting off the ground in 1975 we had the first set of allegations-against Minister Garland who was involved in bribery allegations in the Australian Capital Territory Senate elections. He was charged and had to resign. He subsequently resigned from Parliament and has been honoured with a knighthood for his services to the Government. In 1977 Mr Lynch, who was then Treasurer, had to resign because of dark clouds over land deals involving his family trust in a land speculation company in Victoria. In 1978 there were allegations of favoured treatment for a firm called Stawell Timber Industries Pty Ltd in the Prime Minister's electorate . The same year the Australian Postal Commission bought land at Boondall in Queensland, a deal which involved a windfall profit for friends of the late Eric Robinson, a Fraser Minister. Government Ministers were involved in the rigging of electoral boundaries in 1978, as some people in this House will remember more easily than others. Then we have the still shadowy case of Ian Sinclair's family business-forgery and fraud. In 1979 one Minister, Newman, said that he changed an answer he gave in Parliament after consulting Mr Fraser and Mr Lynch. On the same matter, a former Minister, Senator Webster, misled the Parliament in respect to oil rigging on the Great Barrier Reef.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does this have to do with the Government's 1980 policy speech?
—We are talking about the Government's promise of ministerial propriety and responsibility. We are looking at the record in respect to that promise.
—I take a point of order. I suggest that the honourable senator is reading his speech, Mr Deputy President.
—Honourable senators would know that it is against Standing Orders for an honourable senator to read his speech, but I assume that the honourable senator is reading from copious notes.

—Extremely copious. I will continue. Then we had the case of the now departed Mr Tony Staley who in 1980 refused to take action against Mr Rupert Murdoch, although it was quite clear that the latter had been proven to have breached aspects of the Broadcasting and Television Act. Late last year we had Mr Sinclair appearing once again in the Asia Dairy Industries affair. This list is not exhaustive and it is not comprehensive, but it serves to make a mockery of what the Prime Minister said in these matters. This is, in fact, a government which, more than any other in the history of this country, has been riddled with allegations of skulduggery, dirty dealing, trickery, faslehoods and deceptions. Since 1975 the record shows that 12 Ministers have had to resign, four have been sacked and two have been asked to stand down, have been suspended, until the heat cooled down. Where then is the integrity as promised by this Government? Where is the highest code and practice of public administration which the Prime Minister promised and which honourable senators opposite do not seem to be too concerned about today?

SPEECH.PARA: There is one aspect of this area of policy on which I agree with the Prime Minister; that is, when he says that his Government's record is without parallel in Australia's history. If any other Government had, in fact, achieved the record of this Government in this area it would long ago have resigned. Can we reasonably expect a Government with such a shameful record in relation to its own affairs to honour anything else it says? In every area it has continued to break its promises. In respect to unemployment, the poor, the migrants, Australian women, the sick, the disabled, and the needy, it has broken promises to the workers of Australia, to the taxpayers of Australia and to the Australian people. Despite the words of Liberal-National Country Party members and senators , this Government has not looked after Australians. Through massive cuts in public expenditure in those areas which provide real benefits for Australians it has reduced living standards for the majority of citizens in this country. The Government's response to this might be one of denial but in answer to questions which I have put on the Notice Paper, which already appear in the Senate Hansard and which I do not need to provide once again, the record stands clear and the Government stands com- mitted. As I have said, those records are available to those senators who wish to peruse the table to see how spending priorities have in fact been changed since 1975. It is a table which graphically illustrates the cold-hearted attack this Government has made on living standards.

In the short time available I have only scraped the surface of this Government' s broken promises, and my colleagues Senator Robert Ray and Senator Jones will follow this up. I could also look into the areas of women's affairs, industrial relations and consumer affairs where the promise was made that the Australian consumer would be protected and that the plans of the Whitlam Government would be proceeded with. In the last five years we have seen a growing silence in respect of this area. We can look at waste and extravagance; we can look at the overseas trips; we can look at the current situation of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) who has gone off to a conference for three days but who will be out of Australia for four weeks without justification for the extra time spent. I could talk about social security payments, pensions, welfare and wages. One can look at the Prices Justification Tribunal and the broken commitments made in relation to it. One can look at the Trade Practices Commission and consider the commitments made there. I could mention also the very serious backdowns in relation to uranium export and safeguards, commitments that were made over two elections but which have not been met by this Government. But, overall, this Government's record speaks for itself. It is a record of disastrous deceit which will ring in the ears of every Australian, of every elector in the seat of Lowe this weekend, of every elector in Victoria on 3 April and of every elector in Australia at the next general election.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance on a subject submitted by the Australian Labor Party, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The continual failure of the Prime Minister and the coalition government to honour the promises made to the people of Australia as outlined in their 1980 policy speech.

The debate is about those promises made in the 1980 policy speech and whether they have been honoured. One should remind the Senate and the public that in 1975 the Fraser Government was elected because of the outrageously bad performance of the then Whitlam-Hayden Government. Subsequently, in 1977, following a very good performance by the Fraser Government, the Government was re-elected because of its ability to perform on its promises. Again, in 1980, based upon the performance of the Fraser Government over the three years from 1977 to 1980, the Fraser Government was re-elected. The public, having had the opportunity to scrutinise, first of all, the performance of the Whitlam-Hayden Government, rejected it out of hand. Now, three times the public has looked at the performance of this Government and returned it to office.

The focus of Senator Bolkus's speech was really when he said that the whole strategy of the Government was based on its economic performance. He indicated that it had been abysmal. Indeed, I found it most refreshing to go to the Government's policy speech. It is a very refreshing document because it proves the truth of what we said then and our performance since. The document states that the first challenge that faced the Government in the 1980s was the pursuit of responsible economic management. Responsible economic management may sometimes sound far away from our everyday lives. As the first witness on that statement I refer honourable senators to the economic survey of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development on Australia just published. It is a document which judges Australia, both in the narrower sense of Australia itself and in its performance by contrast with other countries. How does it judge our economic performance? The documents put Australia ahead of other countries in economic performance. It indicates that there will be more economic growth in Australia this year and in the years ahead than in other countries. The basis of this matter of public importance is that the Government has failed in its economic performance. But the report states:

Influenced by strongly rising private fixed investment, mainly associated with large resource projects, the economy expanded rapidly in the eighteen months to mid-1981-the period reviewed in this Survey. The upswing was broadly based.

Let me pause there. Here is an influence by strongly rising private fixed investment. Does anyone know any business corporation or individual that will invest in an economy that is not performing well? The only time that we get strongly rising fixed investment is when we have good performance. The document states:
. . . mainly associated with large resource projects
If one turns to the policy speech, it identifies the fact that we, as a government, were able to attract such large resource projects. The document continues:

. . . the economy expanded rapidly . . . The up- swing was broadly based: most components of demand have been buoyant, employment has continued to rise rapidly and unemployment has fallen for the first time for several years.

That is a contrast to what Senator Bolkus has said. That has been stated by the OECD, not by a partisan Labor senator who thinks he can get some quick trick out of a by-election. It is an objective study of Australia. It states that Australia, measured against its peer nations, is doing better than other nations . Senator Bolkus's second significant statement in that wholly written speech- there were not too many-was that inflation is just as high now as it was six years ago and going higher. Because some doubts have been cast in this place about inflation, I sought figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It indicated that the annual changes in inflation rates from 1972 to 1975 were from 5.9 per cent to 15.1 per cent under the Whitlam Government. It noted that in the March quarter of 1975 the inflation rate was 17.6 per cent. It noted also that the inflation rate fell to 9.7 per cent in 1981 and, as honourable senators know , it is now in the vicinity of 10 per cent. How can a responsible senator say that inflation is just as high now as it was when it was 17.6 per cent, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, in March 1975? The Australian Bureau of Statistics states that in 1975 the inflation rate was 15.1 per cent. That, if I may say, rather puts the statements by Senator Bolkus to shame.

A considerable amount of wordage has been used regarding taxation. It was stated that the Fraser Government was a much higher taxing government than the Whitlam Government although it claimed that it would reduce taxes. So that we will have no doubt, I seek leave for Table 6-Commonwealth Government Budget Receipts 1971-72 to 1980-81 and 1981-82-to be incorporated. If we take the increase in revenue takes year by year we find that in the last year of the McMahon Government, the increase in revenue was 6 per cent. In the first year of the Whitlam Government there was a 28 per cent increase; the next year it was 29 per cent; the next year it was 19 per cent. TALK.START.PARA: —How can we now say that taxation is higher? Australia' s most prominent and very distinguished actuary, Professor Pollard, having studied the figures, said that clearly the last six years had been a period of significant fall in the real income tax burden. Professor Pollard has now produced a further table which shows comparisons between 1974-75 tax, the last period of the Whitlam Government, and 1980-81 tax, the last period measurable of this Government. This table shows that for each of the various income groups after making allowances for tax rebates, dependent spouses and various adjustments, there has been a significant percentage fall in the proportion of tax paid now compared with that paid in the past. I seek leave for this table to be incorporated in Hansard.
—Is leave granted?
—No. It is a shonky comparison, done by a shonky academic.

—I ignore the interjection; it is a matter for the Senate. I will again ask for leave to incorporate the table in Hansard. If the Labor Party refuses to allow its incorporation of course I will make it public in other ways. The Labor Party can only refuse to grant leave because it is frightened of what the table shows. I again seek leave for its incorporation in Hansard.
—Is leave granted?
—Subject to it being noted that that is not a valid comparison; it is a dishonest exercise, done by a dishonest academic who is a toady of this Government.

—I raise a point of order. It is quite intolerable that in procedural matters such as this a senator can be allowed to intervene in a debate. This is a well-known and well used device by Senator Walsh to try to take up the time of the speaker. I ask that that device not be tolerated.

—I raise a point of order in respect to the incorporation of the document. I would have thought it was courtesy, even if it is not in the Standing Orders, for a document to be provided to us before we even consider giving consent to incorporating it in Hansard.

—I would be perfectly happy to show this document to the Opposition and then again ask for its incorporation in Hansard. Repeatedly we grant leave for a document to be incorporated without sighting it. So far I have referred to two tables. One shows that year by year increases in revenue under the Whitlam Government were virtually double the average increase under the Fraser Government. That entirely refutes Senator Bolkus's statement. I have also shown that year by year over the past six years there has been a decrease in the proportion of income tax take. Need one remind the Senate that under the Whitlam-Hayden Labor scales people who earned $7,000 or more paid 35c in the dollar tax, those who earned from $10,000 up paid 45c in the dollar tax and those who earned from $15,000 up paid 55c in the dollar tax. Under our scales in 1980 we had a standard rate of 32c in the dollar tax for people who earned up to $17,000, and that embraced the great majority of all taxpayers. Yet it is alleged there was no reform of tax scales. Professor Pollard has indicated that in the last six years the purchasing power of average weekly earnings rose 6.3 per cent-if that is not performance I do not know what is-average household income in real terms rose 5.4 per cent, household consumption expenditure per household in real terms rose 9.5 per cent, real non-farm gross domestic product per person rose 8.2 per cent and registered motor vehicles per thousand population rose 18.6 per cent-from 419 to nearly 500. Despite price rises the average cost of a car, measured in terms of weekly earnings, fell 5 per cent between 1975 and 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to a matter that the Labor Party was very shy about and which was its main negative campaign in the 1980 election. The Labor Party has said that we have failed to repay the increase in the crude oil levy. If one reflects upon the 1980 Federal election campaign one will see one clear issue. The Labor Party spokesman for national development and energy, Mr Keating, tried to frighten people in the election campaign. He said that under a Fraser Government there would be monumental rises month by month in petrol prices in Australia. He said that prices would rise through the roof to 50c a litre and onwards and that there would be great disaster in Australia under our government. He tried to frighten the people. Thank God the people have not been frightened. Mr Keating has been deadly silent over the last year or so because since the election campaign the real price of oil and petrol in Australia has fallen so that the very platform on which the Labor Party went to the people-that we were the people who would increase the real price of oil-has failed miserably. Rather than the price of oil rising it is falling both in real and nominal terms. How can a party that tried to frighten the people now do these things?

It is alleged that the Government has failed to make good its statement that it would help families through increases it received from the crude oil levy. I make it perfectly clear that there has been no increase at all in the crude oil levy. In fact there has been a decrease, and therefore there has been no increment to disburse. These are the kinds of statements that have been made. Let me look at what has happened. We were elected in 1980, as we were in 1975 and 1977, to manage the economy. The OECD says that we are managing the economy as good or better than our peer nations throughout the world. The OECD sees real growth in Australia compared with other countries. I have shown that taxation, under the Whitlam Government, rose year by year at nearly double the grab of this Government. I have shown using an eminent actuary's figures that the net proportion of personal income tax has decreased. I will take another step and demonstrate the kinds of claims that are made. We are talking of performance. In 1972-73, the last financial year of the McMahon Government, 188,384 dwellings were approved in Australia. The next year the number fell to 179,720. The next year, 1974-75, it fell to 121,323. Over two years there was a fall in approvals of 67,000. That is the record of a party which is now talking about performance. Wherever one looks one will find that, where Labor failed, this Government has performed. It is acknowledged throughout the world by investment flow, by the OECD and by others as performing better than its peers. That is why Australia is experiencing real growth while other countries are in recession.
