SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, is almost a political Rip Van Winkle in many ways. He seems to have lived his greatest years from 1972 to 1975 . Since then rarely has he contributed anything to these sorts of debates other than waving about a couple of economic documents. I do not accept that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development necessarily is the best and only fair analysis of Australia's position, nor do I accept the actuary he has put up as a particularly creditable person. Recently in this chamber we saw the grotesque spectacle of Liberals attacking the Australian Democrats on the basis of broken election promises. I got the impression that certain Liberals opposite would like to gaol some of Don Chipp's small group for a crime that this Government, without exception, has been guilty of. These days the community is pleasantly surprised, even shocked, if the Liberal Party Government keeps one of its promises.

SPEECH.PARA: In defending this Government the Liberals always claim that economic circumstances have changed. One would think they would learn from the past. Of course there will be changed economic circumstances from time to time. That is why it is not creditable to make the sorts of political promises that the Liberal Party of Australia made at the last three Federal elections. Sadly, a majority of the Australian public was gullible enough to fall for the twists and turns in Liberal policy after the 1975 and 1977 elections. The success of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in conning the electorate in no way excuses his pompous and patronising attitude at the 1980 election. He thought he knew best but history has subsequently proved that he did not. The community knows through hard experience that the extravagant and wishful promises made by Malcolm Fraser never had a chance of success, largely because of the economic conditions created by his Government. No doubt, in order to restrain their natural honesty from explaining all this to the community in 1980, the Liberals busily devoted themselves to fabricating non-existent Labor policies. Menzies taught his proteges well-when a party cannot win with its own policies, it should lie and distort its opposition's policies.

The only success the Government can claim from the last election was-Senator Sir John Carrick said it-the belief that it had better economic managers. I have no doubt that the belief existed in the community before and during the 1980 election that members of the Liberal Party were better economic managers. No matter what party one supports one has to admit that that claim looks pretty sick today. We can prove that the conservative government elected for a third time 16 months ago consists of irresponsible, uneconomic mis-managers. It has failed to deliver its fundamental economic promises, and what it has delivered it has had no mandate for. In fact, after comparing the current economic policies of the Liberal and National Country Parties with their promises, or more often their silence, before the 1980 election, the only reasonable conclusion I can draw is that they lacked the guts to tell the public what the true economic conditions were in 1980.

Whilst I realise that many Liberals have limited powers of memory, let us cast our minds back to 1975, 1977, 1980 or any year we like. The current Prime Minister damned the Australian Labor Party for failing to control inflation. He promised that the pursuit of responsible management would be the key to lowering inflation. As faithful neo-conservatives, Government members have interpreted that objective as being achievable only through a restraint of government expenditure. This highly principled policy of restraint has brought inflation, measured by the consumer price index, to its highest level in four years. The 4. 2 per cent increase in the December 1981 quarter brought the annual inflation rate to 11.3 per cent. To be objective, the best way to judge inflation is to take the annual rate and not take it over several quarters. I am not saying that only the Liberal Party has used quarterly figures to make itself look better; the Labor Party has done the same in the past. The election claim that Australia 's inflation rate was below the average for comparable advanced industrialised countries has proved to be short-lived. The OECD document quoted from by Senator Sir John Carrick shows that the average is 10.1 per cent for those countries. In Australia it is over 11 per cent and shows every indication of rising. I think that refutes the point made by Senator Sir John Carrick. At least half this inflation rate has been due to Government policies, such as sales tax, health insurance increases and rising prices forced on State governments-all things for which this Government had no mandate, but which it has forced through. The social impact of inflation can be modified provided one has a sympathetic government. At least in 1972 to 1975 there were schemes to help the Australian people to modify whatever effects inflation had. There are no such schemes today .

Let us look at income tax revenue. In the current financial year it will increase by $3 billion, equivalent to an average of $11 per taxpayer in this country. The Treasury estimates that income tax receipts will rise by 22 per cent in 1981-82. These are later and more relevant figures than those cited by Senator Sir John Carrick. Yet the Government is counting on only a 15 per cent increase in wages over the same time. It is hard to interpret this in any way other than as explicit acceptance by the Government of a policy involving redistribution of wealth from the poor to the rich. No one would pretend it is a secret that the current Government is the highest taxing administration in Australia's history. Until 1981 the Prime Minister and his satraps had taken $ 162 billion from the Australian taxpayer. This year alone, the Liberals will tax Australians almost as much as they were taxed in the entire three years of the Whitlam Government. We in the Labor Party have no objection to high taxation as long as it is slotted in among those who can afford to pay it. By that, I usually mean the friends and backers of the Liberal-National Country Party coalition.

In 1975, when Bill Hayden was Treasurer, pay-as-you-earn taxpayers contributed 41.7 per cent. Today they contribute over 45 per cent. Pay-as-you-earn tax, as a proportion of total income tax, has increased from 59 per cent to 66 per cent. The Prime Minister, 16 months ago, in his policy speech, said:
Tax relief purchased at the cost of higher inflation would be no relief at all.

Today we have higher inflation, and there is still no tax relief in sight, barring, of course, the possibility of some sweetener being put out to help the Government in an early election. In 1975 the Prime Minister promised full tax indexation. Does Senator Sir John Carrick remember that promise? It was never once delivered. After five years of failing to deliver it, in April 1981 it was scrapped for all time. The promise was made in 1975, 1977 and 1980 but it was never once delivered. Today Australians must rely on erratic adjustments of tax scales made for purely electoral reasons. The Australian Taxpayers Association has estimated that, if there is no repeat of the July 1981 adjustments this year , personal income tax will rise by 25 per cent in the next financial year. Is it any wonder that the Labor Party fully supports the efforts of wage earners to defend their declining standard of living? Yet the Prime Minister could offer a real tax cut of at least $9 a week to every Australian taxpayer if he were prepared to tackle Australia's biggest growth industry; that is, the tax avoidance industry which minimally is worth $2,500m a year.

Quite apart from the undeclared schemes, the Commissioner of Taxation has identified 22,000 Australians who have succeeded in avoiding the payment of $1 billion in taxes. Identified tax avoiders have increased by 30 per cent in the last financial year. They have doubled in the last two years. The number of Australians shirking their tax responsibilities is 26 times larger today than it was under the Hayden treasuryship of 1975. There is no mention of this scandal, I agree, in the 1980 policy speech. The Prime Minister's only reference was to partial adjustment of the scales. Sixteen months later the Government has failed to tackle this problem at all. Instead, the Liberals expect salary earners and those on fixed incomes to pick up the slack-a gap approaching several billion dollars. Even a cautious attitude to reforming Australia's taxation system might be understandable if Australia were in the middle of a boom-but clearly we are not. Not even the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is suggesting that we are in the middle of a boom. To be charitable it is not entirely the fault of the Federal Government.

As part of Labor's commitment to a strong mixed economy we recognise that economic recovery in this country will only occur in a joint effort between government and private industry. The Government has failed completely to create a positive atmosphere in which public and private sectors can grow together and not at each others expense. In 1980 the Prime Minister promised he would deliver economic development because 'It means jobs, prosperity and security for Australian working men and women'. Following a downturn in production towards the end of 1981, economic surveys by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Bank of New South Wales suggest that a general expectation exists in the business community to the effect that employment conditions are unlikely to improve in the near future.

We can nail the Government on its failure to stimulate employment growth. The employment market has stagnated in the past 16 months. Job creation succeeded in reducing official unemployment by only 0.1 per cent from 6.3 per cent to 6.2 per cent. Existing job vacancies fell and were only 36,700 in November 1981. In comparison with this sort of neo-conservatism I may be regarded as old fashioned and even Keynesian in my approach. I cannot see how any government can justify the contraction of the public sector demand represented by the Review of Commonwealth Functions and the 1981 Budget when massive human and material resources exist in Australia but are not being utilised. How bad do things have to get before the Government will take action? Ben Chifley engineered the commitment by a Labor government in 1945 to a policy of full employment. For 30 years that policy remained intact. The Labor Party has always stood by it as its number one policy. We affirm it today. In contrast, the Liberal-National Country parties have abandoned any belief in full employment but have never been game enough to tell the community that.

The only good sign recently is that the Prime Minister and his acolyte the Treasurer (Mr Howard) have finally acknowledged that Australia is part of the world economy. I am sure Gough Whitlam and Bill Hayden are suitably gratified to know that the Prime Minister now admits that international economic relations might have some influence on Australia's economic performance in 1975- insignificant though the problems under Labor then look now. The balance of payments situation will no doubt be commented on. All I will do is to add that the real value of Australia's export trade will continue to decline. I emphasise that the Government cannot promise an export led recovery. Of course, the Government has attempted to link Australia's decline in the world economy with our general poor standard of industrial relations. On this I will quote perhaps the only truth contained in the 1980 policy speech of the Prime Minister when he said:
What is happening is the result of our policies.

I believe the Government is pursuing a useless and irrelevant set of industrial laws dreamt up by the ideological honchos who hang around the Prime Minister. In their attempt to set up company unions, to extend the stand down clauses to private enterprise and abolish preference to unionists, I get the sad impression that Government members do not know anything about industrial relations-except, of course, when it comes to Solidarity. By maintaining the Industrial Relations Bureau, restricting the Trade Practices Commission and abolishing the Prices Justification Tribunal, the current Government is guaranteeing a hostile industrial environment. The Prime Minister is attempting to undermine trade union organisation and at the same time undermine the confidence of trade unionists that they can get a fair deal. In April last year Mr Fraser signalled the end of wage indexation. As with tax indexation the Liberals claimed at three elections- 1975, 1977 and 1980-to support adjustment of wages tied to the consumer price index. Yet in the first six years Mr Fraser has been Prime Minister his Government has never once supported 100 per cent indexation. On 10 occasions the Federal Government has stepped in and said there would be no increase at all. The best the Government has ever done is 60 per cent wage indexation. In 1980 the Prime Minister said it was a responsibility of trade unionists to put Australia first.

I do not know what we can do to keep governments honest. The Prime Minister has a pretty good survival record up to now. How he will get out of answering for the country's problems, I do not know. I suspect the only way to get the truth out of this Government would be to put Malcolm Fraser in a hospital-private of course-and pump him full of sodium pentothal. Sadly, however, I doubt that any private insurance fund would cover the Prime Minister for the length of stay necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is appropriate that some emphasis be put on the subject matter that the Opposition nominated to debate today. I quote from the notice of the matter of public importance proposed by Senator Bolkus. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The continual failure of the Prime Minister and the Coalition government to honour the promises made to the people of Australia as outlined in their 1980 policy speech.

That was the subject nominated by Senator Bolkus. That is the subject we ought to be debating today. Of course, it is an old trick that when a subject one does not like very much is being debated one talks about another subject. I think it is very unusual for someone to nominate the subject of debate and then choose to talk about a different subject. I certainly came into the Senate chamber expecting something on the subject of the 1980 election policy speech. Instead, we have had rambling discourses with only occasional references to the 1980 policy speech. These are speeches which could have been given anywhere in Australia on any subject at all by any Australian Labor Party politician with an interest, at that instant, in criticising a Liberal government, but certainly not necessarily speeches on the subject nominated by Opposition senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wouldn't do it in a debating society.

—No, the honourable senator would not do it in a debating society and he will learn that it should not be done in the Senate because other honourable senators get to speak too. Nevertheless, I say that under any rules of debate, including those of the Senate, if people make allegations then the people against whom those allegations are being made do have some sort of right of reply. If Opposition senators want to range far and wide in their remarks, then we can range far and wide in answer to some of the things they have said. We do not have to range quite as far and wide as did Opposition speakers because we have a bit more to say on the subject than they do.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that I certainly entered this debate expecting to talk about 1980 policy promises and what has or, it may be alleged, has not happened in relation to them. Therefore, it is relevant, I think, that I mention to the Senate something about the 1980 policy speech of the Government. I will quote from the policy speech given by the Prime Minister on 30 September 1980. At the beginning he set the tone of the Government's approach to the election and to the three years that would follow the election when it was returned to government. He said :
Tonight, I want to talk to you about the challenges and opportunities that lie before us.
I will take the five points that follow as a key to what this debate should be about. The Prime Minister continued:
First, we must maintain responsibility in economic affairs because, without that, all else fails.
Second, we must harness this nation's resources in a co-ordinated and responsible programme of national development.
Third, we must see that from the prosperity we generate, we provide adequately for those in need.
Fourth, as individuals and as a nation, we must encourage ability and cultivate excellence.
And finally, in a world where there is conflict, division and illusion, we must guide Australia safely through the difficulties and dangers.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not done any of those things.

—It is a wonder that Senator Walsh is not on the speakers list if he knows so much about the subject. In fact, Senator Walsh's side has decided that today he will not get a guernsey. I suggest the honourable senator sit still, be quiet and restrain himself because I will talk about those matters. I will take the first point which concerns the Government's 'responsibility in economic affairs because, without that, all else fails'. It is certainly open to the Opposition to make some criticism of the Australian economy. It is not open to it to be quite as scathing about it as it has been because its record in government as an economic manager was the worst of any government in modern Australian history. We have never resiled from the fact that we have had to make what have been some unpopular--
—Who wrote your speech?
—I wrote my speech. I ask the honourable senator to be quiet and to go and write one of his own senator's speeches, such as the one we had earlier.
—Order, Senator Ray!

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. We have never resiled from the fact that we are in difficult economic times and that tough situations leave no soft options. Of course, we and the Australian people have had soft options presented to us by the Labor Party as it did in 1975, 1977 and indeed, in 1980, which is supposed to be the subject of this debate. We have not pretended at any time-we certainly did not during the 1980 election campaign- that that responsibility in economic affairs, to which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) referred, would be, and is, irresponsibility. It is not. I suggest we must accept that that has been to the forefront of the Government's policies and it has maintained that duty and has acted responsibly. Without that responsibility in economically troubled times our society would be at peril in a whole range of ways. It does the Opposition no credit to come into this chamber and list individual items without putting them into some sort of framework. The Opposition could list today a number of areas of criticism. We could list a whole lot of other areas in which we could show that we are above criticism. That would prove nothing at all. But a general proposition has been put to us and we will debate that general proposition. We assert that we have been responsible in economic affairs and that we have not taken soft options in tough situations. The suggestions that we have failed or that we have not lived up to what we said we would do in 1980 fail on the basis of that test because that is what we said we would do.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point made by the Prime Minister in his 1980 policy speech was:
. . . we must harness this nation's resources in a co-ordinated and responsible programme of national development.

Earlier in this debate the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) outlined some of those areas. Since it is his area of responsibility I do not think there is need for me to speak on that matter at any length this afternoon. However, some points ought to be made in general terms in relation to it because it has been the choice of Opposition senators today to harp on matters such as employment and unemployment, confidence and one thing and another. I will quote some of the figures relating to the state of manufacturing in Australia available as at February 1982. The figures I have before me are as follows:
In the September quarter 1981-
That is, at the end of the first year after the 1980 election-
the real value of manufacturers' sales rose by 0.6 per cent to be 2.9 per cent above the September quarter 1980.

The 1980 policy speech was given in the September quarter. Twelve months later, after a policy speech and an election in which we laid stress on the importance of the manufacturing sector, of investment in business and the opportunities that that gives for raising the levels of employment, we see that the real value of manufacturers sales has risen by nearly 3 per cent. These are the sorts of facts that Opposition speakers like to overlook. The statement on the state of manufacturing continues:
Manufacturing employment grew by 2.3 per cent between August and November 1981 to be 2.4 per cent above November 1980.
Those figures relate to the effect of the Liberal Government's policy on employment and the line that we took then which is part of our philosophy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the overseas figures.

—The honourable senator has been good at quoting figures on unemployment. I ask him to have a look at the growth of employment. I am proud to say that he will find that the State in which the growth of employment has been greatest is my State of Queensland which, for a long time, has had the benefit of free enterprise governments, both federally and in the State arena. Queensland is even ahead of the State of New South Wales which does not have the benefit of a free enterprise State government.
—Tell us what they did to TAA.

—There is a view that the unions had some responsibility for what happened to employment in Trans Australia Airlines. The honourable senator should tell us about that. Employment and the value of manufacturing rose in the 12 months after the policy speech in which the Prime Minister said that our approach to stimulating employment would be to provide a climate of economic stability and responsibility which encourages investment and growth in reasonable and sound ways not in 'make work' ways. The statement continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The trend of manufacturing input and output prices is however encouraging.
The annual rate of increase in the price index of materials used in manufacturing fell from 12.9 per cent in November 1980 to 0.1 per cent in November 1981.
The annual rate of increase in the price index of articles produced by manufacturers fell from 11.8 per cent in December 1980 to 6.8 per cent in December 1981.
It appears that good news is unwelcome to some.
I point to one other critical area of development in Australia in world terms at the moment. The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd made the following statement on 20 January 1982:
Between 280 and 300 petroleum exploration wells are expected to be drilled in Australia in 1982.
This is double the 1981 exploration program and will involve expenditure in excess of $800 million.
A large proportion of the wells, particularly onshore, will be drilled by companies which are predominantly Australian in ownership.
The spokesman said:

. . . the very significant increase in exploration effort predicted for 1982 reflected Australia's healthy political climate when compared to elsewhere in the world, international parity for local crude oil prices, the Federal Government's promise that 'new' oil would not attract secondary taxation, and the success of 23 wildcat wells out of 98 drilled last year.

That is solid evidence and those are solid facts that the policies that we proclaimed in 1980 and that we have implemented are working. That we have implemented them is clear in that area. Promises in relation to those points have been kept.

I regret that time is running short. The third point which was mentioned by the Prime Minister in his policy speech related to providing for those in need. I point just briefly to the recent increases in the family allowance. I say in passing that the Government has already kept every promise that it made in its 1980 policy speech in the social welfare area.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has a very good record.

—Indeed. We are proud of it, Senator. We should proclaim it long and loud, particularly at every opportunity that the Opposition gives us in the Senate. I remind the Senate that the Government announced in its Budget Speech that the family allowance for third and subsequent children would be increased by 50 per cent from January 1982. That has happened. Approximately 540,000 families with 1,860,000 children are now benefiting from this increase, which costs the Government $124m in a full year. Of course, by concentrating on those families with more than two children the Government was attempting to aim that increased assistance at families who, in general terms, could be discerned as most in need of that additional assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth point that the Prime Minister made in his policy speech was:
. . . we must encourage ability and cultivate excellence.

I have but two minutes left which means, therefore, that I can make only brief reference to our policies in those areas. I point out to the Senate that very recently, on 29 January 1982, the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) implemented a most significant policy speech promise in relation to the funding of Commonwealth special research centres generally known as 'centres of excellence' . Additional funding of $16m, additional to recurrent funding, was made available for that. This is a great initiative which will indeed encourage that excellence that we think should be encouraged and harnessed for the benefit of all Australians. In the course of the debate we have had only nit-picking criticism, picking at the edges of what is a highly political area. The first speaker in the debate, Senator Bolkus, referred surprisingly to the Lowe by- election. I suggest that probably the only reason why this debate has been initiated is some general political slanging on behalf of the Opposition in relation to the Lowe by-election. The Government is proud of its record in relation to the promises it made in 1980. It is proud to defend that record this afternoon in debating this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of comments. The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) said we did not refer to the 1980 policy speech. It is my intention to refer to that policy speech and to some of the statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I do not have that policy speech with me-Senator Martin read the preamble-there is one statement by the Prime Minister which I should read and which sums up very clearly his attitude in relation to his leadership in this country. He was speaking at an Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference on 22 January 1975. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership when if they were men of real stature, they would be saying 'we can overcome'.

I think that is a very true criticism of the present leadership of Australia. Let us look at the 1980 policy speech delivered by the Prime Minister of this country. If anyone reads the document they could wonder whether they were reading a Grimm's fairy tale that began, 'once upon a time'. I would like to refer to some of the statements made by the Prime Minister in that fairy tale. One of the statements that made an impression on me was this:
Five years ago we committed Australia to a new sense of direction and national purpose. We have fulfilled that commitment.

It is now more than 17 months, counting this month, since the fairy tale was delivered to the electors of Australia. Let us look at the so-called commitment and the consequences for the people of this nation. It is the product of a fertile imagination or pure self-delusion to assert:
. . . a new confidence is alive in Australia's men and women . . .

That is what the Prime Minister wanted us to believe some 17 months ago. Is it confidence that helps the people of Australia suffer the unemployment forced on them by the policies of this Government. Is it confidence that helps the people of Australia suffer the tax burden that has been put on them by this Government, the greatest tax burden in this country's history? Is it confidence that helps people struggle with astronomical health costs, unnecessary increases in petrol costs, prices on essential goods rampaging out of control, high interest rates- the highest on record-and pension rates that are nothing short of a national disgrace? Any member of this Government who took the time to talk to the people within Queensland or any other State, and particularly those electors in Lowe-I know we mentioned Lowe before-or in South Australia would know what has happened to the confidence Australians have left. We are about to be reminded rather forcibly by the Lowe by-election and the State election in Victoria. I think most honourable senators on the Government side of the chamber would have to agree that the invitation issued to the Prime Minister to participate in the Victorian State election was withdrawn. Now he sneaks into his home in Victoria and sneaks out. He plays no role. I think it was Saturday's edition of the Australian which showed photographs of Mr Peacock electioneering in Victoria, instead of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. He is not even welcome in his home State.

Even if this Government has not lost confidence-I believe it has: the people have-its Budget is in chaos, the cost of living is out of control and the Budget deficit is out of control. The banks are now warning that interest rates are about to go through the roof. What does this Government do about it? It tries to divert the public attention from its hopeless mismanagement of the economy by bringing in industrial legislation designed to provoke the trade union movement and further divide the Australian community. We get into the field of good old union bashing again when we hear about stand downs by employers. We talk about unions of a particular industry. We will have 2,000 odd unions in Australia. It will be impossible to bring about good industrial relations in this country. Let us see how the policy stands up to scrutiny. Seventeen months ago the Prime Minister said:
. . . our balance of trade was the best result for the decade . . .

That is a statement made by the Prime Minister. So it was. We were $2.7 billion in the black, and 12 months later, under this Government, our balance of trade was $35m in the red. The figure for the 1981 December quarter shows a trade deficit of $867m, nearly $1 billion in the red. Again 17 months ago the Prime Minister said:
A measure of our compassion as a society is the extent to which we provide dignity in old age . . .

Is dignity in old age enhanced by the necessity to eat canned pet food in order to obtain enough protein to survive? Is dignity in old age considered when threatening pensioners with asset tests and then going into recess for Christmas , leaving them to agonise over their future security? Touching compassion, is it not, at a time of traditional good will? But that is exactly what the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) did to the pensioners prior to last Christmas. What about the future security for elderly Australians who have paid their taxes into this country's coffers for all their working lives? In 1975 the pension was 23.2 per cent of the average weekly earnings. Now it is the equivalent of 22.1 per cent of the average weekly earnings. The estimated value of this month is 21.6 per cent. There is no reason why the pension should not be raised immediately to the level of 25 per cent of the average weekly earnings. What sort of future security is nutured by people such as Sir Phillip Lynch warning of sweeping reviews of social security payments? It is a measure of the extent of compassion for fellow Australians that is felt by the puppets of the corporate elite who presently occupy our treasury benches. Let us deal with what the Prime Minister said in the policy speech. Only 17 months ago Mr Fraser said:
This year-1979-1980-we achieved the best employment growth for 10 years.

Seventeen months later we are suffering the worst unemployment level for nearly 50 years. It is now more than 6.5 per cent, and that does not take into account the level of hidden unemployment. If honourable senators think that the Government's attitude to the aged is callous they should spare a thought for the unemployed teenagers. Teenage employment in Australia showed a modest growth until the first Howard Budget after the 1980 election. In August 1981 1,100 more teenage jobs were available than in the previous August. If we look bit further we will find tht in September 1981 there were 2,000 fewer than in September 1980 . Teenage job vacancies have maintained a steady decline ever since. In January this year there were 23,200 vacancies fewer than in the corresponding period in 1981. The most disturbing factor is that more than 75 per cent of the decline was in full time work. So much for the employment record of Mr Fraser. I suppose this question should be asked: How much more meaningless rhetoric of this man will the people of Australia be subject to? How can we believe him any more because 17 months ago he said:
. . . we must maintain responsibility in economic affairs because, without that, all else fails.
Again in that fine document-that policy speech-he stated:
. . . this financial year-
Meaning 1980-81-
the domestic deficit will be wiped out altogether.

It was, at a tremendous cost to families and wage earners. I ask honourable senators not to look so worried; it was. In 1981-82 families and wage earners are worse off than ever and the Budget deficit is disappearing over the horizon like the sun going down. Mr Fraser said in his policy speech:
We earlier committed ourselves to reforming the tax scales. We have fulfilled that commitment absolutely.

Honourable senators ought to ask some of the people who are waiting for the vote to come up in this chamber on the sales tax legislation-the indirect taxation-to see whether they believe Mr Fraser has fulfilled the commitment absolutely. Australian wage earners are now paying the highest taxes in history. I suppose it is a case of the rich getting richer and the poor getting the message. The Prime Minister was also quoted as saying:
We have introduced firm anti-inflationary policies--

I suggest that we look at the figures and let them speak for themselves. When the Prime Minister spoke those words on 30 September 1980 the rate of inflation was 10.2 per cent. I suppose that there was a little improvement 12 months later when the rate of inflation was 9.1 per cent. It went from 10.2 per cent to 9.1 per cent 12 months later. But last December the inflationary figure was 11.3 per cent. I say to the Senate: So much for this Government's fine words about the need for the people of this country to exercise restraint. The people are shouldering the responsibility and the burden of the Government's bungling in relation to its economic policies. Probably one of the classic quotations from the Prime Minister's 1980 policy speech is the one in relation to parity pricing policies. It is somewhat of a disappointment to me that Senator Sir John Carrick is not in the chamber to hear me quote the statement made by the Prime Minister in his policy speech. He said:
The giant Rundle shale oil project in Queensland is likely to be the largest ever undertaken in Australia, and one of the largest in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that-Senator Carrick?
—No, the Prime Minister said it in his policy speech. He continued :

SPEECH.PARA: That would not have occurred without parity pricing.

When will this man, the Prime Minister, ever get anything right? We all know the consequences for the motorist of parity pricing. The Rundle fiasco was one of the first development confidence tricks since the Poseidon adventure in Western Australia. Let me give an example. Let us look at the sale prices for the Rundle twins last year when the Minister for National Development and Energy and the Prime Minister were giving such glowing reports and making such glowing statements about Rundle's future. Central Pacific shares peaked at $8.30 when the statement was made by the Prime Minister and supported by the Minister for National Development and Energy. Southern Pacific Petroleum shares were priced at $3.20. Let us look at the share prices for those two companies today. They are listed at 62c and 26c respectively; that is, they have gone from $8.30 to 62c and $3.20 to 26c respectively. It is the depth of irresponsibility publicly to promote a project that has not been proved viable and wittingly or unwittingly to encourage investors to risk their capital and savings in such a gamble for pure political advantage.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement to mark the occasion of Commonwealth Day and to incorporate the text of the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows:

The second Monday in March is set aside to mark Commonwealth Day and as today is the closest Sitting Day, I would like to take this opportunity to emphasise the significance of the Commonwealth, and its importance for Australia.

The Commonwealth has shown a remarkable capacity to adapt to changing world circumstances, especially in recent decades. It has a demonstrated capacity to maintain its own continuity through a process of evolution and subtle modification and at the same time it has a proven track record in solving problems.

As Commonwealth Secretary-General Ramphal said in Melbourne last year, ''it is acknowledged that the Commonwealth can handle disagreement and generate accord'' . He went on to say that ''our dialogue is one between friends within the community of the Commonwealth''. These views have been echoed by dozens of Commonwealth leaders.

We live in a fragile and dangerous world in which there are few enough fruitful avenues open to the nations of the world to come to terms with the problems which confront us. Because this is so, we should all try to nourish and encourage any avenue which exists and which can do good and the Commonwealth is, without doubt, an avenue which has a number of unique advantages. It brings together rich and poor, North and South. It cuts across many prevailing expectations of alignments among nations. It enables people with very different political philosophies to sit down together and work towards agreement on matters that would otherwise divide them.

The Commonwealth is the only forum in which Heads of Government set aside several days of their time every two years-in the case of CHOGRM leaders, every year-to address a range of problems of common concern. The informality and flexibility of the Commonwealth enable it to bring new and practical perspectives to bear on problems where the rest of the world community has sometimes found itself locked into sterile exchanges between structured groups. Commonwealth leaders have shown their determination to make the Commonwealth work. Difficulties and shortcomings have never been allowed to stand in the way, and there is no doubt that the Commonwealth warrants our continuing support.

1982 will be an important year for the Commonwealth. The Third Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting will take place in Suva in October. This will be the first meeting of Commonwealth leaders in the Pacific Islands, and this has a particular significance following the emphasis given to issues of Pacific concern at last year's Commonwealth meeting. This Meeting will involve Commonwalth Heads of Government from the Asian and Pacific regions.

The development of Regional Commonwealth Meetings was, as honourable Senators will know, an Australian initiative. We look to the Meeting in Suva to carry forward the valuable and practical achievements of the two previous Regional Meetings in Sydney and New Delhi, and we would anticipate that a number of the issues considered in Melbourne last year will receive further attention at the Suva Meeting.

The Senate is well aware that there is more to the Commonwealth than intergovernmental meetings-the Commonwealth is about people with many shared interests and values associating together voluntarily. At the time of last year' s Commonwealth meeting, a number of other Commonwealth Associations also met in Australia, and later this year the Commonwealth Games will be held in Brisbane. Everyone in this Senate wants these Games to be successful, and I am sure they will be; and I am confident that the favourable impression of Australia gained by Commonwealth visitors last year will be reinforced among visitors to the Brisbane Games.
The Commonwealth deserves our support across the full range of its activities and it is fitting that this support should be duly recognised in the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Today I would like the Senate to step back from the cut and thrust of everyday political life to consider the direction in which we wish to move as a nation in the next few years. This Parliament has a profound responsibility to keep abreast of the whole range of issues facing Australia. We need to understand Australia's position in a broad perspective as well as in detail, in the light of international as well as domestic factors. We need to understand the choices which lie ahead and the consequences of the decisions we take. We need a clear sense of our nation's values and objectives and we need to develop and explain our policies in the light of our philosophy. The world is full of uncertainty and because of this, Australia needs a policy approach which is marked by balance, vision and realism. The world is also full of unrealistic demands and expectations in spite of the immediate social and economic problems which many countries are experiencing and which are having an indirect impact on most countries. In a situation of significant uncertainty and difficulty, it would obviously be absurd to expect that high and immediate expectations can be attained at little cost or as a matter of course. But neither should we allow the difficulties being experienced by the world economy to be seen in a way which gets them out of proportion-it would be wrong to overestimate or underestimate them. We need to try to understand them realistically because it is vital if we are to move ahead as one nation in the next few years that people 's expectations should be closely adjusted to reality. Nobody has a crystal ball to predict the future fully but we do know that unless we anticipate and adapt our policies in line with changing circumstances, unless we are in a position to take advantage of changes in the world economy as and when they occur, then opportunities will pass Australia by. We also know that the old adage that you only get out as much as you put in remains as true today as it has always been and it is timely to remember, when we are considering realistic levels of expectations, that what some people get cannot go to others.

SPEECH.PARA: The International Perspective

In coming to grips with Australia's present position in an overall perspective, it is appropriate to start with the international dimension. Our independence as a nation cannot blind us to the fact that overseas events affect us profoundly. Much of Australia's history bears witness to the recognition by earlier generations of Australians that we are affected by what happens in other parts of the world. At the present time, Australia cannot ignore the tensions and the threats which exist in so many parts of the world to international security and stability. The Soviet Union pursues its militaristic and opportunistic programs relentlessly. We see the effects of that policy in Afghanistan and Poland and in attempts to frustrate the peace process in the Middle East. We see it through Cuba's support for communist insurrection in Africa and Latin America and, closer to home, Vietnamese troops continue to occupy Kampuchea, in violation of that country's sovereignty, and posing a threat to Thailand.

Without question, the world situation is troubled and uncertain. New trouble spots can erupt with little or no warning. Our policies must take account of the broad global context and we must recognise that Australia's security is bound up with the strength of the Western alliance. We obviously benefit from the security which this alliance brings to us but at the same time we must shoulder the responsibilities which it entails. All of this is part of interdependence and whether we are talking about threats to world peace and security, or about problems of world poverty, or about the slackness of world trade, the growing interdependence of the world must be seen as fundamental.

I would like to say here that the development of multiculturalism in Australia in recent years has helped us enormously as a community in gaining the wider understanding which the successful management of interdependence will increasingly call for. I believe it is a tribute to our responsibility and compassion as a community that Australians have felt involved in tragic events in other countries and have given practical effect to these feelings as shown by the massive public responses to appeals like those for Kampuchea, for Southern Italy after the earthquake and for Poland. The same concern is equally apparent in the willingness of hundreds of young Australians to respond to an appeal to go as teachers to Zimbabwe. Interdependence is real and in managing it we need policies which take advantage of the opportunities it creates, as well as minimising the difficulties and dangers which go with it. The growth of world trade provides a compelling illustration of our growing interdependence, of the advantages it can bring as well as its impact on key areas such as employment.

It was the rapid expansion of trade in the post-Second World War period that was a mainspring of rapid world economic growth that supported the growth of employment opportunities, and of real living standards for countries at all levels of development. Between 1963 and 1970, while the volume of world output grew at an average annual rate of 5.6 per cent, the volume of world exports grew by 8.6 per cent per annum. But during the 1970s, the growth of world output and exports both significantly slowed and as a result unemployment started to get worse. It is particularly worth noting in this regard that between 1973 and 1978 , exports from developed to developing countries rose at an average rate of over 20 per cent. How much worse would unemployment problems in developed countries now be without that trade?

We must also recognise a further aspect of interdependence-that other nations are taking an increasing interest in our economic and trade policies. Others rightly expect us to be good neighbours, to play our full part in promoting the continued orderly growth of world trade as responsible members of the international economic community. It is plain that the growth of trade, and the growth of interdependence more generally, increasingly exposes a nation's economic system to influences from outside its own borders. Our own increased interdependence with the rest of the world has been highlighted by the quite violent economic fluctuations which have been a characteristic feature of much of the last decade.

Each surge in the price of oil has led to a crisis which caused the growth of world trade to slacken and Australia has been affected in a number of ways by both the oil price shocks and by the slackening of trade. There was obviously renewed interest in the exploitation of alternative sources of energy and this has given Australia opportunities. But the slower growth in world markets has affected our exports and any dip in commodity prices due to unfavourable conditions overseas is plainly going to have an impact on Australia. Even before the first oil price increase in 1973, inflation had become more or less endemic in most industrialised nations. Excessive growth of government spending and inappropriate use of deficit financing played a major part in this. The oil price increases compounded these problems, making growing unemployment and growing inflation the order of the day. Even then, most countries did not recognise what was needed in terms of restraint of government spending, in terms of firmness of monetary policy and in terms of wage restraint. Although there are now signs in a number of countries of a determination to pursue more economically realistic policies, natural economic processes have run their course. In Europe and North America, economic growth has virtually come to a standstill in the last two years and unemployment is high, and rising. In France unemployment is 8.5 per cent; in the United States of America it is 8.5 per cent ; and in the United Kingdom it is 11.7 per cent.

By the second half of 1982, total Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development unemployment is expected to rise to 28.5 million people, compared with just over 21 million in 1980. In these conditions of virtually no growth and rising unemployment, overseas inflation rates are falling. The OECD inflation rate is now under 10 per cent and falling, a reduction of three percentage points below the 1980 rate. The United States inflation rate fell from 12.4 per cent in the 12 months to December 1980 to 8.9 per cent in the 12 months to December 1981, and the British inflation rate fell from 15.1 per cent to 12 per cent in the same period. Perhaps paradoxically, sluggish growth and falling inflation have been accompanied by some of the highest interest rates, both real and nominal, that the world has seen. This situation stems from a number of factors.

The situation should be seen against the background that interest rates rose less rapidly than inflation during the 1970s. Real interest rates were negative for a substantial part of that decade. Whilst falling inflation rates in some countries is a cause for optimism, financial markets are not convinced that the underlying problem of inflation has been solved. The present situation has been aggravated by an unfortunate mix of policies in some countries. Budget deficits have been allowed to soar and the resulting pressures on the money supply have only been kept in check with exceptionally stringent monetary policies.

Sluggish growth, low business profits and high interest rates have in turn interacted to produce stagnant investment and continued economic recession. Overseas markets are growing very slowly, if at all. International commodity prices fell 20 per cent in the year to the last September quarter. Australia's farmers are also experiencing generally flat or falling prices along with rising costs and they are also subject to quotas and restrictions of many kinds in international markets. Over the last year or so, and partly reflecting some of the factors I have been referring to, there have also been some significant shifts in the world oil situation. At present world crude oil supplies are more than ample to meet demand but oil prices are still very high. The future levels of energy supply and energy prices are full of uncertainty. Our economy is inevitably constrained, and increasingly constrained by its interdependence with the rest of the world. We cannot but be affected by factors such as the present slackness in world demand, and the high cost of funds, nor can we avoid being affected by the protectionism which strikes at many of our exports, especially our farm products. It is important for us to be aware of the very real dangers that are created by increasing protectionism in other countries during a time of world recession.

Associated with these influences has been a rapid growth in our current account deficit, squeezed profitability for our export industries and some reappraisal and deferment of resource projects. But investment is still moving ahead strongly. We cannot afford, as a nation, to try to ignore overseas developments or their inevitable influence upon us. What we must do is develop appropriate responses. We must be ready to react and ready to adapt, especially to fundamental changes in the world economy while minimising the undesirable effects of unwelcome influences. In so doing we need policies which lay solid foundations for future growth which will allow us to take full advantage of the renewed growth overseas which must occur at some time and which will carry us through the intervening period of world downturn no matter how short or long it may turn out to be. In particular, we must prove ourselves reliable and competitive suppliers. We cannot afford to price ourselves out of world markets, or earn ourselves the reputation of being incapable of meeting contractual commitments because of poor industrial relations.
The Australian Economic Achievement

When we look at Australia's present position in the light of our economic achievements over recent years, it is plain that great advances have been made and a strong foundation laid for the future. Although we are a trading nation and despite the continuing slackness of world trade over recent years, we have swum against the tide. And I believe that in the current circumstances, when the facts of interdependence plainly make our position increasingly difficult, our determination to succeed through farsighted and sustainable policies will be seen as right. It is an undoubted fact that as a result of our policies Australia has prospered in recent years while the rest of the world has been stagnating. Private enterprise has prospered and Australia has benefited. To be sure, we have had valuable resources to exploit and profit by in a troubled world economy. But that did not make success certain for the opportunities we had could have been squandered. Possession of resources is only the first condition of prosperity. Another necessary condition is sound government policy and there is no denying that the policies we have followed have created the conditions in which private enterprise has been encouraged to take the lead in exploiting the opportunities on offer. The confidence required for investment to go ahead has been created and, as a result of this turnaround, the living standards of Australia's families have been improved and we now stand ready to grasp the opportunities which will inevitably lie ahead for us.

A consistent assault on inflation has been essential in creating an environment in which private enterprise could plan and invest with confidence. The sustained restraint which has been imposed on government spending which has been virtually unrivalled throughout the world has been indispensable to success. The interests of all Australians require that this restraint must be maintained along with giving proper emphasis to priority needs and concerns. The Budget deficit has been pulled back from almost 5 per cent of gross domestic product to less than 1 per cent. The Commonwealth has eased the pressure on domestic capital markets by curbing its own borrowing requirements and we look for support in this endeavour from other levels of government. Action has been taken to promote industrial expansion and encourage the growth of productivity and there has been a concern for the competitive position of Australian industry.

While success with inflation has been vital, successful, non-disruptive management of the exchange rate has also been vital. Secure and improved access for our products has been sought on established markets, in the United States of America, Europe and Japan and Australian exports have been helped to make significant gains in new and expanding markets especially in Asia and the Middle East. Industry has been helped by initiatives to encourage industrial research and development and by an accelerated depreciation allowance. Industry has been given due notice of change where reduced levels of assistance are desirable. And to avoid delay in putting in place the stable policy foundation on which industry will be able to plan in the longer term, the general reference on tariffs was brought forward.

Manufacturing industry is indispensable to balanced development throughout Australia and, in 1981, manufacturing industry investment increased by 32 per cent in money terms. The effect of all these policy approaches has been to build Australia up. Their goal, which we all share, has been higher living standards for Australia's families. And their benefits are now plain to see-almost 400,000 new jobs created in the three years to the December quarter, almost 90 per cent of them in the private sector; real household disposable incomes up by $2.9 billion after tax in 1980-81; average weekly earnings up by more than $13 per week in real terms in the two years to the September quarter.

This has been reflected in stronger growth in consumer spending and much stronger private investment in housing; between 1977-78 and 1980-81, investment in dwellings rose by 26.5 per cent in real terms. The gains that have been made also point towards a better future. Business profits rose 17 per cent in real terms in the last three years. With that has come a surge in business investment . The 1980-81 rate of increase was the highest for 30 years. The 1981-82 rate is also likely to be over 10 per cent in real terms. And this, as a share of gross domestic product, will bring business investment back close to the levels that used to be taken for granted in the 1960s.

Business investment is vital to our children's future. It is the only basis of more jobs and more real spending power in the Australian community and this is why it is so important to give high priority to building up the economy. But it is not only in economic matters that Australians expect their governments to apply effective policies. And when we look across a wider range of concerns, there is cause for pride in what has been achieved.

I shall mention just a few areas in order to provide a broader perspective from which to view some of the challenges which lie ahead. In relation to defence, important steps have been taken in the policy of making sure Australia has an up -to-date and balanced Defence Force, including the acquisition of the FA18 fighter aircraft, of the British 105 millimetre gun, and of the aircraft carrier Invincible; and we need to be aware that strong capabilities contribute not only to national security but also to regional stability and security.

In international affairs, consistent expression has been given to Australia's concerns and actions such as our efforts in relation to the issues of world poverty, our decision to take part in the Sinai peacekeeping force, and our contributions through the Commonwealth have helped to build Australia's reputation as a forward-looking, outward-looking and reliable nation.
In the area of tax avoidance, determined measures have been consistently applied-measures which are really biting into this anti-social industry.

In the field of legal reform, the Human Rights Commission and now the freedom of information legislation-the first that will come into place nationally in a Westminster system-are effective measures to meet important community concerns.

In the field of environmental protection, the declaration last year of the new section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park gave further clear expression to the concern for the preservation of our environment which is so widely felt in the community, especially among young people.
In education, the issue of giving our young people the skills they need is being tackled and the increasing emphasis on technical and further education is an important element in this.

Families, especially those with low incomes who received little assistance from the old rebate arrangements, have been enormously assisted by the family allowance scheme which was introduced several years ago and family allowances were substantially increased for larger families from last January.

In the area of social welfare, the automatic indexation of pensions has given income security to a very significant number of people in the community and assistance has been extended to particularly needy groups, such as pensioners facing high rents and sole parents on low incomes.

It is obviously important that governments work to advance the wider opportunities and way of life which Australians want as well as working to secure and improve the material living standards of Australia's families. I believe that, as a result of what has been achieved, Australia is now facing the future from a position of comparative strength for there is great underlying strength in our economy and, as I have said already, we are well placed to take advantage of future opportunities provided we work hard to maintain our strong position.
Challenges and Problems

But it is not only opportunities which lie ahead although they will surely come . As we look ahead, as we form our expectations for the future, we plainly need to recognise that there are also problems and challenges. It is our task to identify them, to explain them, to address them realistically and, having done that, to seek the co-operation of the community in coming to terms with them. One thing which is plain at the present time is that a fresher and sharper breeze is blowing through the markets of the world as our industrial competitors , faced with their own situation of no growth and unemployment, restructure their industries, as they improve their productivity and efficiency and as their inflation rates fall. When this is added to the fact that many markets are, if anything, shrinking rather than growing, it is clear that we shall have to fight harder to sell the exports on which our economic development depends.

This harder competition from overseas comes at a time when there are some problems on our own doorstep. Plainly, inflation remains at the forefront as the principal threat to our economy because, while much has been achieved in pulling inflation back, there are substantial inflationary pressures in our economy at the present time.

Demands for higher wages and shorter working hours have been contributing substantially to these pressures. And in Australia's present situation, there can be little doubt that excessive wage rises and damaging strikes are placing economic progress at serious risk. It is imperative that we recognise as a nation that wage rises which are beyond the capacity of the economy harm everyone and benefit no-one. They cause higher inflation; they threaten our ability to compete on world markets and they create more unemployment. There is no doubt that wage restraint in the next few months is vital to us all for further wage increases at this time on top of the wage and shorter hours settlements of the last six months are beyond the capacity of the economy and time is needed to absorb the increases which have already taken place.

Let me add that there is plainly a continuing need for an appropriately firm monetary policy. In present circumstances, with a weakened balance of payments and strong inflationary pressures, there could be no thought that the money supply would be allowed to expand to accommodate inflationary wage settlements. It is vastly important to us all that demands and expectations should be matched with economic reality as it now is both internationally and domestically. Whatever else may be arguable, there is no doubt that our overall level of economic growth places clear limits on the sustainable real wage increases which can occur.

We must never forget that everything, including wages, has to come out of what Australia is producing. Further limits on wage increases are imposed by the claims of needy and underprivileged people to share the benefits of prosperity and investors also have their legitimate claim for profits, which are the basis of the further investment on which future growth depends. As the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has said on many occasions, Australia would benefit greatly from rational debate on the proper balance between these respective claims and we believe that such a debate could have a most valuable impact in helping every section of the community to decide what expectations are reasonable, what claims are legitimate, and which demands ought to be moderated.

I turn to the industrial front where the level of strikes and industrial disputation is plainly a matter for the most serious concern. The Government is addressing the situation with some important legislative initiatives as part of an on-going concern with reforming industrial relations. First among these initiatives will be the provision giving private employers a right of stand-down in strike situations to bring about a better balance in the bargaining position of unions and employers and to equalise their responsibility before the law. We believe that this measure will help to bring home to unions the real cost to the community of strike action and that it will help bring a degree of balance to the negotiating process. The second initiative is designed to put renewed vigour into efforts to achieve a restructuring of unions more in line with the needs of a modern Australian economy and to move away from a system rigidly tied to craft -based unions. The third proposal, for voluntary unionism, seeks to protect the basic rights of ordinary average Australians.

The Commonwealth is also addressing a number of industrial relations issues in co-operation with the States. Important consensus was reached at the recent Premiers Conference and labour Ministers have already met to consider options to facilitate handling of demarcation disputes and the development of a complementary industrial relations system. In considering the problem of demarcation disputes, the objective must be to protect both employers who are harmed and unions which are attacked.

The Premiers have also agreed to work with the Commonwealth in efforts to seek agreement with unions and shipping interests along the lines of the recommendations of the Crawford report, and to reduce the level of industrial disputation in the maritime and waterfront industries. Thus in co-operation with the States, and through our own legislative initiatives, we are taking a positive approach which should remove some of the hurdles in the path of industrial peace and bring a greater sense of responsibility into industrial relations.

In addition to the threats to Australia's economic well-being posed by wage demands and industrial disputes, there are a number of other issues which are of great concern to the community which need to be explained and addressed with balance and realism. Home ownership is one issue which is causing very considerable concern in the community and nobody wants Australia's high level of home ownership to be damaged. The issue is complex. There are three interrelated problems. The availability of funds, the high interest rates which currently prevail, and the high cost of houses, especially in some cities. At the present time, the Government has this issue under close review and the Government will in due course announce the policy changes it believes are necessary.

Taxation is a further issue of great concern to the entire community and I want to reaffirm that it is the policy of the Government to make further income tax reductions when it is economically responsible to do so. The present tax levels concern the Government as they concern the community and it is important to remember the major taxation reforms which the Government has implemented including initiatives such as the doubling of the rebate for dependent spouses which has taken place, the deductibility of superannuation contributions up to $ 1,200 a year for self-employed persons and others not covered by employer- sponsored schemes, the abolition of death duties, and the tax rebate for health insurance. The cost to revenue of these initiatives alone is well over a billion dollars a year. It is important, when the community considers taxation levels, to be aware of a number of critical factors; the implications for the Budget of an ageing population, the need for increased defence expenditure, and the need to pull back earlier Budget deficits drastically. Consistent with factors such as these, the Government's commitment to lower taxes and greater spending power is clear and we shall continue to follow those policies which provide the only basis for sustainable tax cuts.

I have sought to draw the Senate's attention to some of the major factors which need to be taken into account by the Australian people as we look to the future and seek to match our expectations with reality. Many of the issues which we are facing are complex. Many of the problems do not offer easy solutions and the right balance between competing claims is in many cases difficult to find. But of course it is not unusual for a situation to exist in which expectations are greater than can be satisfied, in which different groups within the community are making claims which are inconsistent with each other, in which some claims can be satisfied only at the expense of others, in which some short-term aims conflict with longer term objectives. It is easy for people in pursuing their own objectives to overlook the claims of others and put at risk the source of the future well-being of everyone.

The objectives of the vast majority of Australians are plain. As a nation, we seek rising standards of living. We seek more dollars in taxpayers' pockets. We seek an increasingly compassionate society. We seek wider opportunities and greater scope for people to develop their talents. We seek greater security for all our people. We seek increasingly efficient public institutions. We seek the conservation of our heritage and our environment and much more as well. All of these objectives are consistent with each other and a balanced policy approach commits us to pursuing them all. But we plainly cannot pursue all or any of them as fast as we would wish. Indeed, in times of economic difficulty and stagnation overseas, we may be committed to pursuing them far more slowly than we would wish because one thing which is vastly important is that in pursuing these objectives, we cannot afford to destroy economic growth itself. Without growth, all our other efforts and objectives will come to nothing.

It is significant that Australia's growth rate in the last two years has been almost twice the OECD average and it is significant that the OECD predicts a growth rate of over 3 per cent for Australia in 1982 against an OECD average of just over 1 per cent. There is growth in our economy but we cannot take the future for granted. In a situation of international uncertainty and world economic downturn, where our own growth is held back by the no-growth situation of other economies, we must surely accept as a community the need to avoid putting at risk the present strength of our economy. In dealing with these issues, it is imperative that we weigh up our own claims and expectations against the kind of growing Australia which we want to build for our children, considering both in the light of the real opportunities which are open to Australia in the interdependent world in which we live because only in that way can we reach responsible conclusions on the decisions which lie before us both as individuals and as a nation. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.
