SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the speech which has been read on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) by Senator Carrick I had difficulty for some time in trying to work out what it was all about, so I looked at the title of the speech and it is called: 'State of the Nation'. In fact, if one examines the contents of the speech it should be entitled 'The State of Malcolm Fraser' because that is what it is about. I want to illustrate briefly, in the time available to me, why I make that allegation. When one looks at the final section of the speech where the rhetoric gets somewhat heavier than in the earlier parts, the key to it all, of course, is what the Prime Minister considers to be the objectives of the vast majority of Australians. That appears on page 10 of his statement. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The objectives of the vast majority of Australians are plain. As a nation, we seek rising standards of living. We seek more dollars in taxpayers' pockets. We seek an increasingly compassionate society. We seek wider opportunities and greater scope for people to develop their talents. We seek greater security for all our people. We seek increasingly efficient public institutions. We seek the conservation of our heritage and our environment and much more as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —That sounds like the rhetoric of a latter-day Caesar.

—Senator Primmer points out, by way of interjection, that that is the rhetoric of 1975; the exception is that in 1975 these things were not being sought by a Fraser government; these things were promised by a Fraser government . They were promised in 1975 in the context of a speech which was called 'Turn on the lights'. In 1982 they are put forward in the context of 'lead kindly light amidst the encircling gloom', a vastly different concept from that of 1975 . What this speech is designed to do is to go some way towards filling the vacuum in Liberal Party thought and it is not a very good attempt at doing so. What it does is reiterate all the old tired rhetoric of Malcolm Fraser which has been going on since the policy speeches of 1975. If one looks at the circumstances which have brought about this speech one will see that they are nothing to do with national problems which are facing Australia. They are matters which concern not only the future of the Liberal Party, which is important to those who sit on the Government side, but also and more particularly the fortunes of Malcolm Fraser. This speech has no purpose in presenting new policies to the Australian people. There are no new policies in the speech. Its point is to try to force some form of public consensus from the Prime Minister's rebellious colleagues such as Mr Andrew Peacock and his erstwhile supporters and Mr Howard and Sir Phillip Lynch. The speech tries to get some consensus.
—Tell us about Bob Hawke and Bill Hayden. Tell us about that.

—The honourable senator will have his opportunity to tell us about that in his speech. The issue of Bob Hawke and Bill Hayden about which Senator Peter Rae interjected is pretty tired stuff. It has all the qualities of this speech about it. It is old hat stuff. The matter which Senator Peter Rae, as the Liberals' answer to a thinking man's politician, cannot avoid is that there are very real problems about this issue in the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Sir Phillip Lynch, is a very dexterous politician in many ways. One wonders why he got his knighthood. Was it his capacity to obtain loans at interest rates lower than anybody else in Australia or his particular qualities as a politician which enable him, as it was once said of a famous American politician, 'to sense the wind and make sure that he will not be caught in the draught'? That is what Sir Phillip Lynch did last week when he entered into relatively unchartered waters for this Government in expressing some views about policies which were distinct from those espoused by the Prime Minister. Of course everybody in this country knows that no matter how people such as Senator Peter Rae may attempt to interject this speech tries to persuade the people of Australia, but more importantly the Liberal Party, that this Government stands for something when in fact it stands for nothing. The rhetoric and ideas have run out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what you would say with seven years in front of you?

—The position of the Prime Minister has become very shaky indeed. If the honourable senator wants to talk about our period in office he ought to read the statement with a great deal more care. It is the first time in the history of this Prime Minister that there is some recognition of the international problems, in terms of the international economy-I refer to the first major oil price rise in 1973-which the Labor Government suffered. This is the first recognition from this Prime Minister in seven years in that office of significant international problems at that time. Why does he give that flicker of recognition now? In the context of this speech he wants to use a global alibi for himself and his failures. I will come to that in a minute. What the speech is about is to try to shore up the Liberal Party and shore up his own position within the Party. It is an insult to this Senate and the people of Australia to call this statement a speech about the state of the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening is that people such as Andrew Peacock are being pursued by the Phillip Lynches of this world before they win succession by default in the Liberal Party leadership. It is simple recognition that the game is up in terms of the rhetoric of the last seven years. The lies and deceptions are finally coming back to haunt this Government. We cannot avoid recognising-and all Australian political commentators cannot avoid recognising-that the cloud of illegitimacy, if I may use that word, which hung over this Government from the very beginning is now getting darker and darker.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reminded of the Arab loans and the Iraqi breakfasts that occurred in 1975.
—Senator Rae's sotto voce interjection suggests that he is rather ashamed of it.
—I am ashamed of what the Government did in 1975.
—The honourable senator is ashamed of what the Government did in 1975.
—Yes, like the Arab loans and the Iraqi breakfasts.

—The honourable senator can make a speech about all those sorts of things but I do not think people will be very interested in what he has to say. The Government's problem is that it promised to do better and it has done worse. That is a problem which it must face up to in front of the Australian people. We have a situation where the Prime Minister comes friendless into this Parliament with a plaintive cry for national unity which he dresses up in the guise of a speech called 'The State of the Nation'. God help us!

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to dwell for any length of time on the sort of cliches with which this speech is cluttered, cliches such as 'opportunities will pass us by' or ' you only get back as much as you put in'. This is the rhetoric of a teenage layabout. The whole speech is larded with such cliches, and I do not want to dwell on those matters. What it is all about is revealed in the first sentence, which states:
Today I would like the House to step back from the cut and thrust of everyday political life to consider the direction in which we wish to move as a nation-

That is what the speech is all about. The Prime Minister is saying: 'For God's sake let us get out of the cut and thrust of politics because I, Malcolm Fraser, am getting the cuts but am not getting too many thrusts. Therefore let us step back and look at the direction in which we are going as a nation'. I thought that the Prime Minister knew all about that because he told us about it in 1975, 1977 and 1980; he told us about the direction in which he was going to lead us. In 1982 he cannot say: 'Let us step back and look at where we are going'. The last person in Australia who can say that is the person who holds himself up as the leader of this society. In 1982 Malcolm Fraser says: 'For seven years I have enjoyed a Prime Ministerial salary because I told you I knew where we were going and where I would take you, but now I want to step back and let us have a look at where we are going'. Therefore the speech is rightly described as 'a state of Malcolm Fraser' rather than 'the state of the nation'. The essence of the speech is contained in the early paragraphs. What the speech is about is to try to establish a global alibi for failures of this Government. Let us look at what the Prime Minister said in 1975 about that sort of thing. He said:

When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, it is part of the world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership when if they were men of real stature they would be saying: 'We can overcome'. Those who suggest that the world is in a cyclical situation, that it will all occur regardless, are equally defeatist and equally wrong.

This is not a 'we shall overcome' speech. This is a speech about the futility of one man's leadership and it is documented throughout the speech. The Prime Minister says, on the contrary, that our history bears witness that we are affected by what happens in other parts of the world-I would hope so-and that we must take account of what he calls the broad global context. That is an alibi which he seeks for himself but which, according to his universally applied double standards, he was not prepared to grant to anybody else. That is what it is about in the terms of the promises of 1975 and the performances of seven years after. The speech is cluttered with figures which purport to show how well the economy has been managed in the last six years. His policies having failed, he is now trying desperately to talk up the economy. What is the truth of the matter? We now have an unemployment rate of 6.4 per cent of the work force, the highest level for a year. Interest rates are at record levels. Home construction is down by 9 per cent. The latest balance of payments accounts show a deficit for the first seven months of the current financial year of $2 billion. The share market is at its lowest level for more than two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is at its lowest level since the middle of the Whitlam Government.

—What does that prove? Senator Rae says that the share market is at its lowest level since the middle of the Whitlam Government's term in office. Perhaps he will make a speech later and tell me what that proves about anything. His party was saying before the last election that the low share market was indicative of people's fear that a Labor government might get into power. It was not half as low as it is now.
—It was lower.

—Not before the last election. Senator Rae argues by way of interjection that we should operate in this society by politics of the lowest common denominator-the 'my dad is a policeman' sort of argument. What he says by his interjection is: 'We might be a dreadful Government but, my God, the Whitlam Government was worse seven years ago'. What has that to do with anybody living in this country in 1982? His party's promise was that it would do better. That is Senator Sir John Carrick's sort of lowest common denominator argument about politics. Senator Sir John Carrick, who is fixated in the period 1972 to 1975, is a classic example of Freud's definition of neuroticism-he has an unhealthy obsession with the past. It detracts from his ability to be a successful Minister in 1982. That is the sort of argument which Senator Rae is putting by interjection. Before he interrupted me I was talking about the share market. I was going on to talk about the collection of defects in this Government's performance. The whole strategy of the Government this year assumed a high level of foreign investment in Australia. That has not occurred at the level that the Government planned for. We in Australia are now in an inflating economy in a deflating world. That is another achievement about which, in terms of the promises of this Government, I scarcely need to put salt in the wound. I think even somebody as insensitive as Senator Rae will understand the point I am trying to make. I am speaking medically, not in terms of his natural disposition . The cost of living in Australia went up 4.2 per cent in the December quarter. Tax avoidance in Australia is reaching record levels. It has become a $7 billion a year industry. Nothing has been done, in spite of the Prime Minister's words in this speech, to check tax avoidance in a significant way.

SPEECH.PARA: The alibi of members of the Government on the tax avoidance issue is to say: ' But the Labor Government didn't do much about it'. The Labor Government never controlled the Senate. The Labor Government had two elections in three years. When the Labor Government went out of office the level of tax avoidance, as recorded in the reports of the Commissioner of Taxation, was about 900 cases a year. In the same report this year the number is 22,700. Tax avoidance has been the only growth industry under the Fraser Government. We know why it has been a growth industry and nothing has been done about it. It has nothing to do with all the good intentions which I am sure people on the Government side have. Tax avoidance is a big industry because Malcolm does not want to upset his friends who are involved in it. It is an industry which goes to the heart of an incapacity of any government to do anything about politics which is honourable in a country such as this. We cannot have an industrial relations policy, a prices and incomes policy or any policies which are predicted on the notion of a fair society while tax avoidance is as rife as it is now under this Government. The interim report of Mr Costigan, the Royal Commissioner inquiring into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, sets out clearly how widespread this industry is. The next test for the Government will be whether that Royal Commission is given powers to subpoena documents from the Taxation Office.

Despite the level of tax avoidance, the Government has tried to impose new sales taxes whose effect will bear more on wage earners than the very rich. Already taxes have risen by $3,000m this year. This is the low tax party! This is the Government of the Prime Minister who says in the final stages of his speech that he knows what all Australians want. One of the things they want, he says, is to pay less tax. He could have fooled them. I think he has done so in the past. I do not think he will fool them much longer. In the six years of office of the Fraser Government tax collections from ordinary people, income earners, have risen by 144 per cent. One could go on discussing the taxation issue to which even this Government seems to be becoming slightly sensitive. The Prime Minister, in the context of his speech, mentioned a number of other issues . He mentioned housing. I am surprised that he saw fit to mention housing. This is a government without a policy on housing. He also mentioned industrial relations. This is a government without a wages policy. When the Government plucks the eyes out of the report on Australia of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development one of the things to which it is blind and which it does not pluck out is the one which indicates that Australia is a country without any wages policy. I think most economists would agree that that goes to the crux of the issue of economic management.

On the question of housing, let me record for the benefit of Government senators some of the facts. Many home owners in Australia are being forced to sell their homes because they cannot afford to make repayments at current interest rates. That is a very sad fact. It is sadder in terms of the integrity of government that that has happened under a government whose Deputy Prime Minister promised at the election before last to eat his hat if interest rates did not go down by 2 per cent. They have gone nowhere but up since then. The number of private houses under construction has fallen by 12 per cent in a year. The number of public houses under construction in December alone was 11 per cent lower than the year before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Public houses?

—That is a good interjection. I concede Senator Rae's concern about this matter. If the number of public houses in Australia were down by 11 per cent, Senator Rae would be worried stiff because he is a big user of public houses. What I meant by public houses was welfare housing, as it is sometimes called, or houses provided by the public purse.

SPEECH.PARA: The next issue to which the Prime Minister refers somewhat ominously is a fairly traditional one; that is, the pending legislation on trade unions. I think this is about the eleventh piece of industrial legislation which is designed to solve industrial relations problems in Australia since the Fraser Government came to office. Of course, this legislation is designed to cause discontent and disruption so the Prime Minister can again raise the argument-it raised in 1977 and 1980-of who is running the country. This is a traditional and conservative stunt. It is a totally cynical application of public policy for political purposes. That is all that the industrial relations policies of this Government amount to.

The Senate needs no reminding that one of the important provisions of this legislation will be to provide for restructuring of trade unions which will not be on an honest basis but be carried out in a way to attempt to cause industrial disruption. I remind the Senate of the legislation on union amalgamation which we debated late last year but which was defeated by the Government, it being a private members Bill. I think the industrial relations posturing is important in the context of scooping the barrel of Liberal Party rhetoric when a degree of desperation arises. Of course, in the negative sense it goes along with all the talk of standards of living, more dollars in taxpayers' pockets, a compassionate society conserving the environment and all that stuff.

The standard of living of the average Australian is down and is falling. Taxpayers are paying more tax; fewer real dollars are going into taxpayers' pockets. No real dollars are coming out of the tax avoiders pockets. The level of compassion of this Government is shown in its harassment of the sick, the poor and the disadvantaged. But while all the fundamental Government policies which might be directed to a consideration of the questions which the Prime Minister poses as to where this country is going and where it is being led are allowed to languish, the security of this country will be guaranteed by squandering the best part of $1,000m on a single naval ship-referred to with some apparent pride in the Prime Minister's speech. Clearly that ship will be vulnerable and unable to pay its way in defence terms. But, of course, that is not the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you support a motion of disallowance?
—Yes, but that is not the issue, is it? The Invincible has nothing to do with Australian defence policy. It is a symbol of all that is rotten in the state of Australia.
—It has quite a bit to do with CHOGM.

—I am indebted to Senator Rae. In case the Hansard reporter did not record the interjection, I will repeat it. Senator Rae said that it has quite a lot to do with the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. It probably has. Senator Rae is something of a symbolist, if I can use that word. I do not mean in the musical sense but as someone who has an addiction to symbols. The Invincible is a symbol, as is CHOGM. They are both symbols of the Australian antipodean version of what used to be called Sukarnoism in days gone by when that gentleman was President of Indonesia. That is to say, one concentrates the rhetoric on overseas matters, on symbols, on anything rather than the real issues which confront the people over which the so-called 'leader' presides. The Prime Minister's speech was about abdication of leadership. It is a speech which expresses in its own words total concern, anguish and disillusionment about where this country is going. It is a speech which I find incredible to think any so-called leader in a democratic society could have made after seven years of the rhetoric and performance of this man. In a sense I suppose that it is probably a swan song. When old people sense they are going, they tend to write something down for posterity. The Prime Minister is not so old but I sense that he is going and he wants to say something for posterity. He is saying, 'Well, for God's sake it wasn't so bad after all, was it? We have been in government for seven years and we are still concerned about the sorts of issues which we promised to provide solutions to in 1975'. Full marks for consistency of concern ; no marks for leadership, good government, integrity, honesty or any of the qualities which might in leadership go to make this country great.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we have heard a typically brilliant, amusing and telling speech by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). Unfortunately, it was reasonably predictable. I am afraid it was a point scoring performance. Without a doubt, a lot of points were scored but that does not really get us very far. I draw the Senate's attention to what the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) had to say in the opening words of his speech and I will go no further. He asked this Parliament to step back from the cut and thrust of every day political life to consider the direction in which we wished to move as a nation in the next five years. I believe that this Parliament ought to give careful and urgent consideration to that offer. This country is in a critical situation. It does not advance the cause of the people of this country one bit to try to apportion blame. What we have to try to do is to get out of this critical situation. We will not get out of it unless we embark on some long term thinking and planning.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister in his statement clearly outlines a desire to do this. I believe we should take him at his word. He did not outline a mechanism as to how this can be achieved. He suggests the Parliament should be the mechanism which, quite obviously, is an impossibility. But the issue is far too important for the Parliament not to consider how some long term indicative planning could be achieved. The Australian Democrats believe that we should engage the best brains in this country to try to achieve our goal. We call it indicative planning. We are not talking about rigid planning such as is carried on in the Eastern European countries. We are talking of an indicative plan that sets out the options that are available to Australia in 1982. It can be done. We can quantify the options that are available to Australia. It is done in countries such as Japan, France and Sweden.

TALK.START.PARA: —Austria.

—It is done in Austria. It can only be done if we set up a planning mechanism to achieve it. The Prime Minister has made the suggestion; we propose that that suggestion be taken up to see whether we cannot get a planning mechanism. There is no other way we will solve the very real problems that face this country whether we are governed by a Labor Party or a Liberal Party. We must set goals; we must set medium term goals; goals for the next five years. We cannot have everything of everything; we have to make choices and we have to quantify those choices.

SPEECH.PARA: By and large, private enterprise has come to realise that some measure of economic planning is not against its interests. In fact, I believe it realises very clearly today-more clearly than the Government has hitherto realised-that the preservation of private enterprise can be achieved only if it is operating within a framework of national economic planning which takes note of the community's needs. How is this indicative planning done in countries such as Japan? It is done on a co-operative basis. There is a planning authority. The choices available to the country at any one time are discussed with a representative cross-section of the community. The choices are discussed with business leaders, trade unions, consumers and political parties of all persuasions. It is not a point scoring discussion. It is a discussion that looks at the options that are available and what the country can afford and then makes choices-more of this and less of something else.

We do not have to go further than the defence situation to realise how little long term planning occurs in this country. I wonder whether the Navy has ever been asked to face up to the problem of how much money it has to spend over a five year term or, if it spends X amount of dollars on an aircraft carrier, what will happen to the rest of its requirements. The same applies to the Army and to the Air Force.

More importantly, what about business? The one thing that business must have is some firm framework on which to build and to do its own planning. If the rules are being changed every year business cannot operate. If we had in this country a plan that had been thoroughly discussed and could be taken up by business with confidence knowing it was realistic, within the realms of possibility, and that it could expect Government co-operation if it moved in a certain direction, we would achieve great things.

This planning has to take advantage of computer techniques that have been evolved over recent years and which can give us very detailed information of the options that are available. This planning technique does not require a large bureaucracy; it requires high powered computers. It does not require a lot of people; it requires continual consultation with the interest groups in the community. We cannot sit down and set a plan and say: 'Here it is' and that is set for the next five years. It has to be continually discussed-at least every six months-and modified in the light of changing world circumstances.

But we have no planning at all. We have just seen, with a Budget that was brought down only a few months ago, that we cannot even plan successfully for the next 12 months. Why can we not plan? The answer is that we are attempting to put before this country options in isolation from community interests. There is no real consultation with business or with trade unions. If that could be achieved, if we could get a new approach, if we could get intermediate term planning, we would have some chance of solving the problems that lie ahead.

Lastly, I draw attention to the very real possibility that, apart from national medium term planning, I am sure that we could, if we tried, take some note of world trends in the future. We are living at a critical time in human history-of that there is no doubt. The pressures of an exponentially growing world population on depleting resources are creating new problems for the old world and for the new. We inevitably have to move towards a sustainable economy that is in equilibrium with world resources, with the environment and with other life systems.

Various organisations have attempted to establish a world model. I have seen some of them. The Club of Rome was probably the leader in this field. All these world models show one fact very clearly: Our society will not move to a sustainable condition easily. To develop renewable energy sources, as every computer model clearly shows, will require enormous expenditure in human effort, manpower and capital. When we talk about the advances in technology and the dangers of there being insufficient work for the people of the world, we have only to turn our attention to the problems of the future in trying to arrive at a sustainable economy to realise that what is required is not a shorter working week or concern about unemployment but turning attention to the real problems of the future and to get our priorities right. Getting our priorities right can be achieved only through a planning process on a national basis and, insofar as it can reasonably be accurately predicted, on an international basis.

The Prime Minister has made an offer. The Australian Democrats welcome the suggestion that this country step back for a moment from the cut and thrust of politics to consider where it is heading in the medium term. I call upon the Opposition to join the Australian Democrats in putting pressure on the Prime Minister to be as good as his word. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a brief statement on the same subject. I will not be long as I know other important business has to come on tonight. Some matters of fact should be cleared up. This speech which was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and pompously entitled 'State of the Nation' is an attempt by Malcolm Fraser to recover the credibility he lost with his own back bench when, three weeks ago, he sent in the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to reply to the censure motion on the Government. Now, three weeks later , he has mustered whatever courage he has and his wordsmiths have put his lines together. The result is a schizoid document, the first half of which blames external influences and presents a series of excuses for failures which can no longer be successfully denied, and the second half of which is a re-run of the boasts, false assertions, misrepresentation and wishful thoughts of the last six years. They might well have been taken from the writings of the Stumpy Gully Kid , vintage 1966 and 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: Here are some of the specific excuses:
. . . Australia needs a policy approach which is marked by balance, vision and realism. The world is also full of unrealistic demands . . .
It takes a good deal of audacity for a man with Malcolm Fraser's record to condemn or to castigate unrealistic demands. He said:
. . . expectations should be closely adjusted to reality.
In coming to grips with Australia's present position in an overall perspective, it is appropriate to start with the international dimension.

We cannot but be affected by factors such as the present slackness in world demand, and the high cost of funds, nor can we avoid being affected by the protectionism which strikes at many of our exports, especially our farm products .
That is the first half of the speech. External influences are responsible for failures which can no longer be successfully denied.

Contrast that with the bold words of 1975 when Malcolm Fraser was telling the nation that he had the answer to all these problems. He said at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference:

When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership when if they were men of real stature, they would be saying 'We can overcome'.
This speech is an apologia which fails. The first part contradicts the Prime Minister. The second part is riddled with crucial errors of fact. For example:
When we look at Australia's present position in the light of our economic achievements over recent years, it is plain that great advances have been made and a strong foundation laid for the future.

The foundation is unemployment at almost record levels, inflation back in double figures, growth down, record interest rates, record levels of taxation and a balance of payments crisis with all those indicators moving in the wrong direction. Some foundation for the future! He said:
It is an undoubted fact that as a result of our policies Australia has prospered in recent years while the rest of the world has been stagnating.

That is not true. In fact if we look at the years 1977-80-these figures are taken from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Economic Outlook No. 30 published in December 1981-we will see that the average unemployment rate for Australia has been 6 per cent. The average for the entire OECD over those four calendar years was 5.3 per cent. Individual countries, notably Austria, have average rates very much lower again. In Austria's case it is 1.6 per cent. In 1977-80 Australian real economic growth in gross domestic product was 2.3 per cent and the OECD average was 3.1 per cent. Austria again recorded an average growth rate of 3.2 per cent and Japan recorded 5.1 per cent. In relation to consumer price index increases, popularly equated with inflation, the Australian average for 1977-80 was 9.9 per cent, the same as the OECD average. Austria, to use the same example, had an average inflation rate throughout that period of 4.8 per cent.

It is simply not true, however often it may be asserted by the Prime Minister and his toadies that Australia's performance relative to the average of the OECD , let alone to the leading members of the OECD such as the Netherlands, Austria, Japan and West Germany, has been good in the period this Government has been in office. It is correct that in the calendar year 1980 and the latter part of 1979 economic growth in Australia was somewhat higher than it was in other OECD countries. That is a situation which is changing very rapidly and the average Australian inflation rate which used to be the crucial determinant of economic performance by this Government, has now passed OECD levels and is now moving in the wrong direction. The Prime Minister has asserted:
. . . the living standards of Australia's families have been improved and we now stand ready to grasp the opportunities which will inevitably lie ahead for us.

It is correct that for the financial year 1980-81 over 1979-80 there was, as the Prime Minister asserted, an increase in disposable household income in real terms of almost $3 billion, but there are two important things which the Prime Minister does not bother to tell us. The first is that in that same period there has been a substantial increase in the number of households and that a great deal of that gain-about half of it-reflects an increase in the number of households rather than an increase in actual average household income. The second point is that the figures he uses are not the most recent figures which are available. In fact the most recent figures available are for the September quarter of 1980-81.

In that quarter average income per household, in September 1981 value dollars, was $4,994. In the September quarter 1980, in the same value dollars, it was $5, 023. The difference is not vast but the plain fact is that, contrary to the belief which the Prime Minister would implant, on the most recent available figures household income is lower than it was a year before. Those figures, I might add, make no allowance for other factors which have adversely affected household income such as the re-imposition of health insurance payments and the very much higher interest payments. It is true that in the last calendar year and for a few months before that wages had risen at a faster rate than inflation , but household income, on the most recent figures available, has actually fallen compared with what it was 12 months before. The reason for that is what the Prime Minister used to denounce as the great tax rip-off, the secret tax of inflation. Figures published in the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 October last year, for example, show the tax bite on single income families. A family on a single income with a dependant spouse and two dependent children in fact paid in real terms $18 a week more in income tax in December 1981 than it would have paid in December 1975. Certainly, family allowances have increased since then. They account for about half that decline in after tax real income.
The final matter that I want to comment on is this: Probably the greatest misrepresentation of fact in this document is the assertion by the Prime Minister in regard to tax avoidance. He said:
In the area of tax avoidance, determined measures have been consistently applied-measures which are really biting into this anti-social industry.

The most recent report of the Commissioner of Taxation shows that some $920m tax is outstanding in disputed returns, a figure which has quadrupled in the last 12 months. Other authorities, notably Professor Mathews, put the actual current cost of tax avoidance to the revenue at $7,000m per annum. Far from stopping tax avoidance, as the Prime Minister asserts, the Government has legislated on numerous occasions to facilitate tax avoidance. Much of the effect of this was drawn out in a series of 64 questions put on notice last year by my colleague Ralph Willis, the answers to which came back last month. Of the 65 tax concessions he specified only one-third could be costed, but the cost to revenue of that one-third that could be costed was $1,140m. Mostly those tax concessions have been inserted by this Government. Most of those which have been inserted by this Government are agricultural tax concessions of which at least half of the members of the Cabinet are direct beneficiaries.

I shall give a few examples. The answers to Ralph Willis's questions show that the cost of the current arrangements to primary producers' tax averaging is $ 215m a year. This is the arrangement which the Treasury secretary publicly described as an arrangement under which heads farmers win, tails all other taxpayers lose. The cost of investment allowances for agriculture was $75m and $ 20m for accelerated depreciation allowances when all the available empirical evidence shows that farmers already have a propensity to over-invest in plant and equipment, without being encouraged by stupid taxation laws to do so. An amount of $95m of revenue was forgone to facilitate the misallocation of resources. Most scandalous of all in principle if not in quantity were the income equalisation deposit arrangements under which-again half the Cabinet members are in a position to benefit directly from this-a taxpayer may lend $10, 000 for one year, borrow $15,000 for two years and pick up a bonus of $4,500, half of which is tax free. I repeat: A taxpayer may lend $10,000 for one year, borrow $15,000 for two years and pick up a $4,500 cash bonus, half of which is tax free. That rort has been written into the taxation legislation by this Government in the last couple of years.

If we look at the aggregate effect on revenue, according to the answers to Mr Willis's questions, we will see that the cost of that rort to revenue in the most recent year was $29m. The net gain in the trust account was $28.3m. It is costing the revenue more than is accruing in the trust account. All this is from a government which expects restraint on the part of wage earners when it indulges in such predatory rip-offs of the rest of its citizens through the taxation system.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present a report dated 5 March 1982 upon an efficiency audit of the Auditor-General's Office.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON GOVERNMENT CLOTHING AND ORDNANCE FACTORIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report and transcript of evidence of the Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories on its inquiry into the future of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I thank the other Committee members and the Committee staff for their co- operation and diligence in a very difficult task. The Committee agreed at least on the basic headings that are used in the report, those headings being 'Defence ', 'Commercial' and 'Social'. We also agreed basically on part A of the report. But as time unfolds other Committee members will tell their own story about how they disagree.

The Committee's task was to investigate the future of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, given the decision contained in the Review of Commonwealth Functions to sell the factory as a going concern. The decision of the Senate to form a select committee to investigate this matter arose from the concern of the people of Bendigo and the factory employees at the decision to sell. Initially, the essence of the Senate commitment was the expedition of the report but there are sometimes reasons, as most honourable senators know, for taking very special care and deliberation. In any case, in this particular inquiry interested Bendigo people themselves counselled the same care and deliberation that we were compelled to exercise in considering all of the evidence. I think the recommendations of the Committee should come first. The recommendations are as follows:
I. The effort to sell the factory as a 'going concern'-suspended for this inquiry-be now pursued with maximum vigor, and a particular effort be made to show the work force the benefits of sale.

II. As an incentive to prospective purchasers, the factory should retain certain defence contracts presently unique to its operation. Favourable consideration should be given to the inclusion of suitable parts of new projects such as the 105 mm UK light gun and ammunition and other work.
III. There be no replacement of personnel or equipment from the date of this report, unless it facilitates the sale of OFB as a 'going concern'.
IV. If these efforts fail, then the possibility of sale of various sections of OFB as 'going concerns' be investigated.
V. If all the preceding moves fail, then OFB be wound down with an official closure date to be fixed by the Government to allow time to conclude existing commitments.
VI. In the event of a wind-down to closure:
(i) existing apprentices have priority of placement in Federal Government services, locally or elsewhere;
(ii) other employees be given maximum help to relocate at Maribyrnong or elsewhere, or to retire;
(iii) all necessary machinery for continuity of defence projects to be transferred to OFM or elsewhere; and
(iv) the balance of assets of OFB be sold, either with the factory or separately.

I say that in the circumstances of the Committee's decision the people of Bendigo need not fear a decision to sell the factory. The OFB was set up as a defence factory primarily to manufacture naval ordnance. It is a matter of record, however, that since the war years defence orders of this nature have decreased drastically, so much so that the factory has had to undertake commercial work in order to provide a work load. The evidence from the Department of Defence did not indicate an urgent demand for the retention of the factory as it is. Significantly, the Department was unable to give any assurances about increasing defence work load into the factory. Without these assurances, the Committee found it hard to impossible to justify the existence of a factory which is operating at less than half capacity. I might add that half of that half capacity is taken up with commercial work at a cost to the taxpayer of millions each year.

In regard to the commercial aspect of OFB's operations, the Committee found that this was a very expensive way to maintain production levels at the factory. The commercial work undertaken has not proven profitable to OFB. It is true that it has enabled skills to be maintained. However, the Committee is not convinced that the skills are so unique and their maintenance so necessary to Australia's future defence industrial capacity. What is a fact is that commercial work, priced it would seem, at a break-even return to OFB, has done nothing to contribute to the cost of maintaining the factory. This is what the taxpayer has had to bear. If a decision on the factory's future could have been made solely on the basis of defence needs and commercial considerations, it is unlikely that the factory would still be operating in its present form. In fact, Senator Button in his dissenting report makes the following comment:
. . . the decision to sell the factory could probably have been made by a government at any time in the last 20 years-
That this is so is undoubted, yet Senator Button now argues that it should be retained.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might do me the justice of quoting the passage in full and not selectively.

—Senator Button will get his turn in a minute. He suggests that the factory should be given a greater defence work load and more profitable commercial work. This can be done only at the taxpayers' expense. The evidence presented to the Committee has shown that the factory has actively sought a greater defence load since the war years. I think we all commend the factory staff and management for their efforts in this regard, but conditions of peace, the demands for a different kind of weaponry, the high cost of manufacturing in Australia compared with readily available overseas purchase and the fact that our production runs are too small make it inevitable that such requests from OFB could not be gratified. It is true that the factory could be filled with work, but at what cost and what gain?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Siddons in his dissenting report has cited many examples of equipment that could be made at OFB. This equipment could also be made at the Ordnance Factory, Maribyrnong. This factory also has an excess capacity. By concentrating work at OFM, skills will still be maintained and a defence industrial base will still exist capable of expansion in time of difficulty, or, if necessary war. Further, if OFB is sold as a going concern and receives some defence orders, this will also help to maintain the defence industrial base. Except for the 4.5 inch gun and mountings which are being phased out, OFB and OFM are basically duplicating facilities both of which are underutilised. Clearly, this is not the way to achieve full value for the taxpayers' defence dollar. In the past five years the cost to the taxpayer of maintaining OFB has been $24m. For reasons advanced previously, the facts are that work load has not arrived at OFB and the factory has remained at less than half capacity, requiring heavy annual subsidy to survive. The Committee felt that this situation could not continue.

It is true that the employees at the factory and the people of Bendigo are concerned at the possible social and economic effects of the announced sale. The Committee received and considered a great deal of evidence on this aspect. However, it is clear that the social and economic effect of not selling the factory would be far greater given the view of the Department of Industry and Commerce, as expressed in its submission to the Committee, that if the factory were not sold as a going concern it would be wound down to closure within five years. It is for this reason, as well as the other considerations I mentioned earlier, that the Committee's recommendation was for a sale as a going concern. This, combined with the recommendations regarding work load to the factory, would result in less effect on the Bendigo region than the alternative of complete and immediate closure.
Summarising the evidence, the majority report under the heading 'Defence' states:

Neither the capacity nor capability of Australia's defence would be affected by the sale of OFB as a 'going concern' and indeed would be only marginally affected by closure. There is clearly excess capacity to defence requirements and has been for the last twenty years.
Better value for the defence dollar could be obtained if the 'maintenance of production capability' subsidy and other high local production costs did not have to be paid.
Under the heading 'Commercial' it is stated:

OFB is now mainly a commercial factory with a perceived legal problem as a consequence. A mixture of defence and commercial output would be a viable commercial enterprise, and this was the best possible compromise for OFB's future.
Under the heading 'Social' it is stated:

The concern of employees as to the social consequences of a sale are not ignored. The consequences of a sale as a 'going concern' need not be as pessimistic as that outlined in many submissions to the Committee. This conclusion is based on private enterprise bringing a mix of commercial and defence work to OFB.

I believe I should mention some other matters. Several reports over the years of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence have made what I would say are dutiful statements about greater defence procurement being placed with the Australian munitions industry. Such reports at least were sensible enough to add 'unless there are clear and overwhelming national interest reasons for overseas purchase'. I am glad this was done because nowhere in the reports of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence is the Bendigo Ordnance Factory singled out for specific mention as absolutely fundamental to Australia's defence. The majority report of the Committee feels that there are several compelling reasons at the moment for the purchase of our defence equipment-not all of it, but what we are purchasing-overseas. I mention this because it will be suggested that we ignored all the work of previous committees. Indeed, I was a participant in some of those committees.

The second matter I want to mention is the proposed amendment of Senator Siddons as circulated in this chamber several hours ago. It seems to me that this amendment hardly relates to the task we were given to report on. It seems to me, with due respect to Senator Siddons, that it is political grandstanding in the context of an election that is taking place in a particular State. I know honourable senators have the amendment in front of them. In the first part of the amendment Senator Siddons has charged the Government with failing to provide modern guns and missiles for the ships of the Royal Australian Navy. It seems to me that, in the first place, this is not true. Secondly, these are matters for a general defence debate. In terms of the scope of the report, I do not think that we were really meant to cover such matters. With due respect to the present capacities of the OFB, I do not think that it is capable of handling the missile part of Senator Siddons' amendment. The other part of the amendment I would draw attention to is Senator Siddons' charge that the Government has shown lack of planning in the aerospace, munitions and shipbuilding industries. He may well have added in that little catalogue the history of the world and chided us for that, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the honourable senator's attention to the fact that the proposed amendment of Senator Siddons is not before the chamber at this stage. If and when he should move the amendment that has been circulated, the honourable senator will have the right to speak to that amendment. I ask him to speak to the terms of his motion at this stage, which is that the Senate take note of the report.
—Thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy President. I unhesitatingly accept it. I move now to the conclusions of the Committee. Under the heading 'Defence' it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government decision of 30 April 1981 to offer the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, for sale as a 'going concern' was completely correct in all the defence circumstances pertaining then and now.
Under the heading 'Commercial' it is stated:

Commercial ideas and philosophies introduced into what has been up to date a closed government shop have great potential to enhance Bendigo's future and our Australian defence capabilities, with better value for the defence dollar.

Bendigo would, of course, be far better off if the Factory could be sold as a commercial venture than if it had to be closed immediately or wound down and closed and this has been a major consideration in the Committee's decision. The apparent unwillingness of the professional and wages staff to work for private enterprise, obvious at the hearing--
This was regrettable to some of us who were there-
and shown in the evidence, is difficult to understand.
Under the heading 'Social' it is stated:

The considerable amount of social impact evidence was mainly based on the option of failure to sell, leading to closure and neglected entirely the benefits of sale as a 'going concern'. The Committee noted the social impact evidence and, whilst sensitive to the views of the local people, believes that sale as a 'going concern' is the appropriate answer.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, together with Senator Martyr, was a member of the Senate Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories. The decision to sell the Bendigo Ordnance Factory was made in the context of the report of the so-called razor gang or Review of Commonwealth Functions committee of April 1981. As Senator Martyr pointed out to me during the Committee's deliberations, at the time the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee was discussed in this chamber I had some uncharitable things to say about it. Indeed, some of those things which may have seemed uncharitable at the time seemed to have a certain retrospective validity. For example, the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority which resulted from a decision of the razor gang was described the other day as abolishing one quango and creating another. It is in that context that my general view about the Bendigo Ordnance Factory was, in a sense, developed right from the beginning.

SPEECH.PARA: One could say that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory is a quite crucial industry in the city of Bendigo. Senator Siddons, who expressed in a minority report his concerns about defence issues particularly, has drawn attention to that report to the defence implications of the closure of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. My concern in a quite separate dissenting report was to try to draw attention to some other issues which I want to mention to the Senate in the context of the discussion of this report. First of all, in my view the likely consequences of the sale to private enterprise of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory are equivalent to closure. In announcing the sale to private enterprise in April 1981 the Government tried to adopt a device which would avoid the political odium of closing the factory directly. Indeed, if one goes back to October 1980-this is one of the sad parts of the history of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory-one finds in the context of an election in that month the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier) talking about an $8m expansion program for the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. Pre-election the Government, through probably its self-appointed spokesman in this area, talked about expansion; post-election-four months later- the Government was talking about a sale which inevitably, in the view of most members of the committee, meant closure. Devicies were adopted to avoid the political odium of closure.

One can discuss the effect of the sale. Members of the Committee understood that no sale would occur at this point. Probably no genuine buyers are available to the Government. In November last year Sir Phillip Lynch, seeking to distance himself as it were from the decision to sell-he was chairman of the ad hoc committee which decided on this course-and the question of closure of the factory, wrote to the people in Bendigo that if the factory were not sold to private enterprise it would be as a result of the Senate Committee considering the matter. As a consequence of that, the sale would perhaps not take place and it would be necessary for the Government to close the factory. So much for the political devices which have been involved. Indeed, those political devices have created the environment for consideration of this matter.

I just make a few points about this exercise which seem to me to be important. The consideration of the sale or closure of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory is not a matter about which, apart from things I have said, I wish to make partisan political capital. I make the point that this action represents a crisis of government. It would not matter which party was in government, the same problems would be there and the same problems would have to be faced up to. It is in a sense a crisis of government because the situation with regard to the Ordnance Factory represents a chronic lack of leadership and mismanagement at the government level and the departmental level here in Canberra rather than at the level of the factory itself. I think all honourable senators were impressed by the equipment and the level of skill in the factory among both the wage labour at the factory and the engineers who perform the design and supervisory functions. There is a very strong semblance of a sort of cohesive highly skilled and quite dedicated and efficient labour unit-some 650 employees. I think we in Australia have to think very hard about the issue of getting rid of a facility such as the Bendigo Ordnance Factory with such apparent glibness as has emerged in the Government decision.

I stress one or two points. Firstly, we must consider that the social effects on the economy of a city like Bendigo, if this factory is closed, will be significant. There are 650 people employed in the factory. A lot of evidence was given to the Committee-Senator Martyr referred to it-about the effect of closure in terms of unemployment-in terms of the needs of families which are involved in unemployment to relocate, if that were possible, if another job were available and so on. I do not want to dwell on the social aspects. I just stress the fact that these maters are, in my view, quite crucial to a proper consideration of what should be done about the Ordnance Factory.

They are important also in terms of the so-called lip service given by governments to decentralisation policy. Bendigo is a regional city. A lot of its work force is dependent on the factory because Bendigo is an isolated city in terms of the labour market generally. It is, I think, very important to emphasise, for example, that there is a very good record of industrial relations at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. It has a regional flavour about it which one does not get in a large metropolis like Sydney or Melbourne. So aspects of regional policy and attitudes towards decentralisation are important as social issues in relation to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The social effects, of course, would be important wherever they were but they are very important in the context of a country town.

The second point I make is that I do not think that Australia should glibly be prepared to lose a facility of relatively high technology, engineering and skill where the skills relate not only to the machines and the equipment which is there but also to the capacity to work them. The relationship between employees and machines in terms of a creative capacity is not often found in establishments of this kind in Australia. So, when the Government talks about shifting the factory's capacity to Maribyrnong or somewhere like that, it is not , in my view, facing up to the issues of the capacity involved in terms of the work force and equipment which are available and understood by workers in that factory. There would be a result not only of social dislocation but also of dislocation of a skilled labour force. I think that is an important thing which we consider. It is being considered -in spite of what Senator Martyr says-in general terms by report after report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

One of the extraordinary things is that there is no response by the Government to the sorts of attitudes expressed in the report about the need to retain defence technology in Australia and to retain technology generally. It is probably only this sort of government which could consider disposing of that technology without the opportunity being taken to find an alternative course in relation to that facility. A number of reasons are given in the majority report, and indeed by the Government whose views the majority report reflects in a sense , as to why the factory should be sold. First of all, it is pointed out that the factory has a relatively small work load. Its work load is in two areas: Firstly , defence work and, secondly, so-called commercial work.

I just deal briefly with the question of defence work. The Committee in the evidence before it was, in my view, given a very sad and shoddy story of the defence procurement process in Australia. The Committee was presented with diagrams which explained the defence procurement process. The diagrams looked like the inside of a transistor with steps going from one level to another. One finds that a small percentage of time in the manufacture of a particular weapon is devoted to the actual manufacture as distinct from very lengthy departmental process in relation to procurement. That is not just my comment; similar comments have been made by the Australia Defence Association and in, of course, reports to the Parliament by the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee.

I think there is a case to be answered in terms of government management of this factory. The attitude has been to sort of turn a blind eye to what is happening at Bendigo, to forget about it, and then wake up only when a razor gang report is presented. There is no cause for pride in terms of government management of this factory. I refer to the period of the Labor Government as well as to the period of the Fraser Government. There is no cause for pride at all in government terms in relation to defence procurement policy.

The second thing that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory can do is commercial work. It has the technological capacity to do it. The factory does a number of things for bodies like the State Electricity Commission, the various hydro-electric authorities and some big mining companies in terms of building equipment associated with dredges and things of that kind. It does very highly skilled engineering work. According to the evidence given to the Committee, it would be wrong-it has been government policy over many years-for the Bendigo Ordnance Factory to canvass commercial work on a large scale. I think it is important to understand the reason for this. It was actually said by one witness that if the factory did more than 50 per cent commercial work that would provide a challenge to the constitutional validity of the very existence of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory because it is established under the defence power of the Constitution. If an establishment exists under that power it is not possible for it to engage in a great deal of commercial work.

That opinion, that Government policy, in my view-I hope it is not too late for the Government to rethink this question-results from a complete misunderstanding of what the law is-from a complete misunderstanding of the so-called 'clothing trades case'. This was a case in which the High Court was asked to consider whether the Australian Government Clothing Factory at Coburg could perform a large amount of commercial work making uniforms for the railways and tramways and things like that. The interpretation which seems to have been placed on that case is that the High Court said: 'No, that is not right. As long as it does not do too much of that commercial work, it can continue in existence under the defence power'. That is a totally wrong interpretation, in my view, of what the clothing trades case said. It said, in fact, that, if it is the opinion of the Executive Government of the day that it is necessary to retain a skilled work force with a view to defence contingencies, as long as that opinion exists it is okay for that work force to retain its skills and to be employed in whatever work is available to it. The second aspect of the work load of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory is its capacity to do commercial work. That has not been exploited by any government in the past because of a total misapprehension of policy.

The third aspect of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory's malaise, if I can call it that, is simply that no efforts have been made by governments in any real way in Australia to investigate the possibility of Australia becoming a manufacturer of weapons of one kind or another or of weapon components for export. When we asked witnesses from the departments about this, some desultory references were made to trade commissioners talking about it in Manila or somewhere a few years ago but, as the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has also pointed out, there has been no policy of attempting to obtain overseas contracts for work which would have provided longer runs for the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. So, in relation to Government policy, three issues to me seem important: Inadequate defence procurement policies, which have been the subject of earlier criticism by other committees of this Parliament, to which criticism the Government has made no response; secondly, a total misconception about the capacity of a facility like this to engage in commercial work; and thirdly, the absence of policies in relation even to investigating properly the question of a capacity to do defence work in longer runs with a view to overseas sales. In my view, government-I use the word 'government' in the very neutral sense-has been guilty in relation to all those matters and the Ordnance factory has been singled out for condemnation as a result of government inertia and government failure in relation to those matters.

The next thing said to be important is the question of cost to the taxpayer. I think this is a very important issue-the question of what this factory is costing the taxpayer. There seems to be agreement that it was in the order of $8 .5m last year. Senator Crichton-Browne indicates that the figure was $9m. There was some debate in the Committee about this question, but let us say that the figure was $9m last year; I do not think it matters terribly. That was the cost to the taxpayer in 1981, according to the Committee. If one looks at that figure in terms of the factory itself, one finds that, in terms of cost to the taxpayer , the Government is paying a subsidy of about $12,500 a year per worker. The figures are included in the minority report written by me.

I might refer the Senate just briefly to some equivalent industries. For example, in a heavy engineering factory which is manufacturing gear- shafts and couplings, which is totally privately owned and which employs 710 people in Australia-about the same size establishment as the Bendigo Ordnance Factory-the taxpayer subsidy provided by the tariff rate works out at about $14,000 per employee per year. I shudder to mention the car industry, knowing Senator MacGibbon's view about that matter, where, of course, a lot more employees are involved and the subsidy is higher still. So, when we talk about cost to the taxpayer in defence industry and we indulge in this somewhat rhetorical exercise about the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, we find that the cost to the taxpayer in a whole area of human endeavour, whether it be by tax avoiders or whether it be by government decision in relation to tariffs, is significantly higher than the cost to the taxpayer per worker in the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.

Secondly, if we look at a sale to private enterprise and what the cost to the taxpayer would be if the same arrangements were made in respect of costing of the defence equipment and the private industry continued to manufacture the defence equipment, as suggested by the Department of Industry and Commerce, again we find that the cost to the taxpayer in a year would be in the order of $ 5m, to start with; and that avoids the question of other subsidies such as the investment allowance and so on which would be available to a private entrepreneur. So, the difference between the cost involved for the taxpayer in continuing government ownership and in private ownership, in my view, is not significant.

One aspect of the evidence which is most unsatisfactory is the estimate given by departmental witnesses of the costs to the taxpayer in the event of closure of the factory. We really did not have any hard evidence on that point because the departmental spokesman denied, of course, that there would be significant unemployment following the closure of the factory, if it occurred. The cherished belief is that a sale to private enterprise will produce, as Senator Crichton- Browne said in one flamboyant cross-examination of a witness, some vigorous, dynamic private enterprise entrepreneur who will get the factory on its feet in a matter of months. That was the epitome of his particular comforting vision- something which perhaps we all require in a sense-of what might happen, which made him feel better about his decision. I just do not believe that that will happen. I believe that, if a private entrepreneur buys the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, it will be for the purpose of asset stripping. I believe the social consequences of unemployment, which will be very costly, will follow from that sale asset stripping exercise and consequent retrenchment of staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you not make it a condition of sale to maintain a certain level of employment or output?

—With respect, I do not think we can do that. One either sells somebody something or one does not. If one sells somebody something, one sells the right to manage the factory. Any company involved in it for private enterprise purposes, unless it was the Salvation Army or an organisation like that, would not be involved in it for the purposes of keeping people in work if profits were not being made.
—I thought you might be able to negotiate a certain minimal level .

—I do not know why the Government, having made the silly decision about the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, would single it out from every other establishment in Australia and require it to have a certain level of employment, which the Government has not done elsewhere.
—I wish we had been given the motor car industry to look at.

—I would be happy to hear any examples. I would be delighted because it is a good principle. It is one that they adopt in Ireland in relation to employment. It is not one that we have grasped here. I do not think we can have a conditional sale. I do not think we could sell the factory on the condition that they keep a number of workers and produce certain things. I do not think that is possible. In any event it is totally contrary to Senator Crichton-Browne's vision because any dynamic establishment as he envisages it would not be faced with those sorts of alternatives.

SPEECH.PARA: So there are a number of factors relating to this matter which go, I think, to poor performance by government-I am not seeking to make a particular partisan point about that-and which are illustrated by inadequate procurement policy, a false policy on commercial or private work being performed by the factory, and inadequate policy in relation to defence equipment sales. All these things have been brought to the attention of governments before by earlier committees and have not been acted on. Government senators have this totally cynical approach to this institution which, I think, is a sort of damaging thing in terms of the fabric of government. These sorts of things have not been done in the past. We get this situation where there is even a promise of better things to come.

Before the last election there was an expansion program for the factory and then four months later an announcement that it was to be sold. So there is that bad level of performance by the Government which I regard as a relevant factor. If the policies which the Government, or governments, have been criticised for being deficient in had been adopted in the past, then we might have seen a much better result from the factory and a greater work load, greater productivity and so on. Senator Crichton-Browne nods his head; he agrees entirely that the record of governments in the past in their approach to the matter has not been good. I think those matters have to be taken into account. It is important that they be taken into account in conjunction with important issues of social policy like the effects a sale of this kind has on a community such as Bendigo.

There has also to be taken into account the whole question of regional policies and how far governments are going to retreat from the provision of jobs in regional areas. I think that is important. Those and the very telling social demoralising effects to which I referred are quite fundamental to any decision about this factory. The other important point which I do not want to dwell on at length because I know Senator Siddons has a lot of comments to make about it, is one with which I basically agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have to introduce new legislation at 10.20.
—We are going on with this matter tomorrow, are we not?
—Order!

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President, I was trying to deal with an interjection which was helpful because I did not have that information. Let me conclude by saying that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory should continue in government operation. But I do not think it should continue with the sort of lacklustre performance of government that there has been in the past. There needs to be quite a radical change of government policy in order that this factory might operate as a more viable enterprise. In the course of my report I said that one felt at a certain stage, in listening to the evidence, that the factory ought to be retained and the Department of Defence sold to private enterprise. There is some cynical validity in that comment because one cannot actually blame the Department. There is a whole area of government which has been, in my view, neglectful of a resource which has been available to us as a nation which has not been used and which should be used more in the future. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:
'but the Senate expresses its concern with the method of implementation of Government policies and, in particular:

(a) the failure of the Government to respond and act on various reports of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence relating to defence procurement, Australian defence priorities and Australian defence industries;
(b) its failure to provide modern guns and missiles for the ships of the Royal Australian Navy;
(c) allowing the Government Ordnance Factories to run down through lack of work , while ordering weapons from overseas which could have been manufactured in those factories;

(d) failing to secure adequate guarantees on cost, delivery, offsets, Australian industry participation and technology transfers for defence material bought overseas, particularly in the case of the Leopard tank and M198 155mm Howitzer programs;
(e) a lack of planning in the aerospace, munitions and ship building industries ;

(f) the failure of the Government to give adequate weight to questions of social policy, including employment, and the consequences in social terms for the economy of the City of Bendigo if the Ordnance Factory is sold, or closed; and
(g) the failure to relate Government policies in relation to the Ordnance factories with other policies relating to industry support,
and calls on the Government to respond and expand the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo under its present management'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators have been made aware of the general thrust, findings and conclusions of the report from the Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories. The Government members of the Committee found that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory possessed few industrial processes necessary to defence production and that most tasks performed at the Ordnance Factory could equally be undertaken by other Government factories or by industry generally. They found also that the factory was not vital to present defence requirements and even immediate closure of the factory would only marginally affect Australia's defence capability.
—What would they have said if it were in Fremantle.

—Indeed. The majority report concluded that a decision to offer the factory for sale as a going concern was completely correct in the defence circumstances pertaining then and now and recommended this course of action. I wish to completely dissociate myself from those findings and recommendations. I cannot understand how open-minded senators listening to, reading and observing the evidence can draw these conclusions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ordnance Factory at Bendigo is an efficient operation. It is as efficient as any operation could possibly be, given the fact that it has been starved of defence work for a long time. I believe that the Government should continue to run the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo but that it should, at the same time, ensure that a steady and increasing percentage of defence work is given to that establishment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it not getting more defence work?

—I am coming to that if Senator Watson will be patient. I do not wish to bore honourable senators with a lengthy description of the history of the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo and the Select Committee which the Senate appointed to study its future and the future of the Clothing Factory at Coburg. Suffice it to say that I found my membership of the Committee profoundly interesting, hard work and intensely frustrating because of the impossibility of agreement as to the future of the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo. This became apparent very early in the Committee's deliberations. Perhaps I was unduly optimistic in hoping that a non-partisan consensus could be arrived at. However, that indeed was my hope. It proved a tragically faint one. Despite my frustrations I believe an examination of the factory has been worthwhile. Scholars and those people who seek development on an increasingly self- sufficient arms industry in Australia will have if honourable senators will forgive the pun, much ammunition in the future. The evidence provided to the Committee depicts a sorry tale of malevolent neglect, of appalling planning, of decisions made for the most shortsighted and narrow reasons, of an incredible waste of human resources, and of a tragic folly. That we, as a Committee, have been able to shed some light on an industry of such strategic importance has been useful.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not optimistic, however, that the mistakes of the past will not be repeated. The Ordnance Factory at Bendigo was originally built during the Second World War to manufacture large naval ordnance and to repair large naval guns. Twice in the 1960s the future of the factory was reviewed. Each time it was decided that the sale of the factory was not worthwhile and that it should not be proceeded with. Neither the Government nor the evidence presented to the Committee has convinced me that the situation has changed one iota. I now seek leave to continue my remarks later so that legislation can be introduced into the Senate.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
