QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are all unemployed persons given fares if referred to jobs by the Commonwealth Employment Service; if not, why not.
(2) What information is given to the unemployed at the time they are referred to jobs.
(3) What are the criteria for (a) refundable, and (b) non-refundable fares.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Only those job-seekers who satisfy the eligibility criteria of the Fares Assistance Scheme may be assisted under it.

(2) If the Commonwealth Employment Services (CES) considers job-seekers eligible for assistance under the Scheme, they are advised of their entitlements by the CES and encouraged to make use of the Scheme.

(3) (a) Refundable fares assistance is available to job-seekers registered with the CES who are not eligible for non-refundable fares, and where it would be difficult for them to meet the cost of travel to the premises of a prospective employer. In such situations the job seeker concerned undertakes to repay to cost of the fares to the Department. Return journeys from the premises of the employer are not provided in this case.

(b) Non-refundable fares assistance is available to job-seekers who are in receipt of unemployment benefit or who have lodged a claim for unemployment benefit 7 days prior to seeking this assistance. Non-refundable fares assistance is designed to enable unemployed persons registered with the CES to travel free of charge on public transport from the CES office to the premises of a prospective employer and from there, either to the person's home, back to the CES office, or some other reasonable destination.
The Fares Assistance Scheme provides assistance in respect to job-seekers travelling by public transport only and is not available for circumstances involving private arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have research studies begun in the United States in 1972 into sudden infant death syndrome shown a definite causal link to air pollution.
(2) Will the Health Department obtain a copy of a research report relating to sudden infant death syndrome from the County University of Southern California Medical Centre when it becomes available.
(3) Has any similar research been carried out in Australia.
(4) Are any Commonwealth funds available for Australian research into sudden infant death syndrome.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am aware of the research directed by Dr T. Hoppenbrouwers of the Los Angeles County/University of Southern California Medical Centre, concerning a possible seasonal relationship between sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) and environmental pollutants. A report of this research was published in the ' American Journal of Epidemiology,' Vol. 113, No. 6, pages 623-635. I have arranged for a copy of the report to be placed in the Parliamentary Library. The report acknowledges that the statistical data gathered by the researchers do not prove a causal relationship between SIDS and environmental pollution, but suggest that theoretical considerations and evidence from other studies would support such a hypothesis. The research did not, however, establish a scientifically proven link between SIDS and air pollution.
(3) So far as can be ascertained no similar research has been conducted in Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Development Association and Asian Development Fund

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken by:
(a) the United States Administration;
(b) the United States Senate;
(c) the United States House of Representatives;
(d) other countries on the:
(i) Sixth Replenishment of the International Development Association (IDA); and
(ii) Second Replenishment of the Asian Development Fund (ADF)
since the answer provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to my Question No . 455 (see Senate Hansard dated 31 March 1981, page 957).
(2) To what extent had the lending activities of the IDA and the ADF been reduced or deferred by failures to contribute to the replenishments since that answer.
(3) To what extent have donor countries:
(a) made bridging arrangements; or
(b) reassessed their contributions since that answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (i) During 1981 the United States Congress passed legislation authorising the full United States contribution of $US3.24 billion to the Sixth Replenishment of the International Development Association (IDA 6). However, the legislation provided for the United States contribution to be made over four years rather than three years, with steeper graduated payments than allowed for in the IDA 6 Governor's Resolution. (Other donors' contributions, including Australia's, are being paid over a three-year period.) The United States subsequently paid its first instalment of $US500m, which triggered the effectiveness of IDA 6 on 24 August 1981. As advised in the answer provided to Question No. 455, 17 countries, including Australia, participated in a bridging arrangement which enabled IDA to continue its lending program in advance of IDA 6 coming into effect.

In December 1981 the United States Congress passed a new aid appropriation bill . Under this legislation $US700m was appropriated for the second United States instalment to IDA 6 which is $US150m short of the amount included in the authorising legislation for financial year 1982.

Under the IDA 6 Resolution, the pro-rata drawdown arrangements provide an equitable and balanced system for the utilisation of donors' contributions, as well as being designed to encourage all donors to lodge their contributions on time. Give the difficulties faced by IDA, donors agreed to a retrospective waiver of the pro-rata provisions in relation to their first instalments; Australia joined in this consensus. This action enabled IDA to preserve its commitment authority to the maximum extent possible in 1981, despite the delays and shortfall in the United States contribution.

However, most major donors agreed that it was also necessary to maintain the pro-rata provisions in relation to further instalments in order to encourage the continued participation of the United States in IDA 6 and, if possible, to obtain a renewed commitment by the United States to participate in accordance with the terms of the IDA 6 Resolution. Australia joined the consensus and agreed to the application of the pro-rata provisions for the second and third instalments of IDA 6.

(1) (i) As advised in the answer provided to Question No. 455, the Asian Development Fund (ADF) lending program proceeded normally during 1981 following the payment of the United States second instalment in December 1980. On 1 January 1982 the United States paid its third instalment, thus releasing the fourth and final instalments of other donors. Accordingly, the Asian Development Bank's (ADB) 1982 concessional lending program is proceeding satisfactorily.

(2) (i) The shortfall in the first and second of four United States instalments has led to a total shortfall in IDA's commitment authority for 1982 of $US1.5 billion. A further meeting of IDA donors is scheduled to take place in April 1982 to assess the situation. In order to partially offset the loss of these funds, the World Bank management is considering a range of measures, including new criteria for eligibility for concessional IDA loans as well as raising the level of non-concessional lending by $US800m. However, the net result will be a decline in the 1982 level of World Bank lending by $US500m.

(2) (ii) The Second Replenishment of the ADF is still on course and the Bank's concessional lending program continues to progress normally. Consequently, the question of bridging arrangements does not arise and donor countries have not reassessed their contributions.
(3) See (1) and (2) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of Press reports (Sunday Mail, Brisbane, dated 8 November 1981) regarding the serious nuclear pollution problems at the French Pacific nuclear test site at Mururoa Atoll where gale force winds and huge waves on 22 March engulfed a 30,000 square metre heap of contaminated nuclear fallout and carried it into the Atoll's Lagoon.

(2) Was some of this waste material subsequently put into plastic bags which are floating in the Lagoon because the necessary concrete cylinders cannot be made from the Mururoa sand since it also is too contaminated.
(3) Is Mururoa to be abandoned and the French nuclear test facility transferred to another atoll, possibly Fangatofa, 40 kilometres from Mururoa.
(4) Has the Department of Foreign Affairs confirmed these reports.

(5) Will Australia be applying appropriate pressure on the French Government to abandon its Pacific testing program; if so, and if the French Government is unresponsive, will the Government consider refusing to grant export licences for uranium to that country and demand the withdrawal from Australia of any French uranium mining companies operating here or take other retaliatory action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. It is relevant to note that the Sunday Mail article on 8 November 1981 appears to have the same source as an article which appeared in the French daily newspaper Liberation on 6 November 1981. The Sunday Mail article uses the term ' fallout' on several occasions. The Liberation article does not refer to 'fallout ' but uses the French word 'dechets', which translates into English as 'wastes', and covers all categories of physical contamination resulting from nuclear testing activities.

(2) The statement in the Sunday Mail article that 'some loads of contaminated waste have been put into plastic bags which are floating in the Lagoon' would appear to refer to a passage from the Liberation article which reads, in English translation, as follows:

There are now enough wastes on the Atoll to fill 200,000 concrete cylinders of 200 Litres capacity, measuring one and a half metres in diameter and height, which should be buried at a depth of 2,000 metres. The trouble is, to make concrete you need sand, and the sand on Mururoa is contaminated. Some cylinders are for the present partly submerged in the Lagoon. Most of the waste material is in vinyl bags, four or five times thicker than garbage bags.

The Australian Government has no information which would tend to confirm or deny the specific claims made in this report. The French Government has acknowledged that residue from atmospheric nuclear tests conducted before 1975 was scattered by a storm at Mururoa Atoll on the night of 11-12 March 1981 but has stated that the situation is fully under control.

(3) There have been suggestions in the media from time to time that the French authorities are considering reactivating their nuclear test facilities on Fangatofa Atoll for use in addition to, or instead of, those on Mururoa Atoll. The French Government has made no statement on these reports.
(4) As indicated above, the Department of Foreign Affairs has not been able to confirm these reports.

(5) Yes. The Australian Government has directly urged the French Government to cease its nuclear testing program in the South Pacific and has given its active support to statements expressing opposition to nuclear weapons testing in the Pacific at the South Pacific Forum in August 1981 and at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in October 1981. Moreover, the Australian Government strongly supports the conclusion of a treaty which would prohibit the testing of nuclear weapons by all States in all environments. Conclusion of such a treaty would considerably increase international pressures for a complete end to nuclear testing and leave those states which continued to carry out nuclear explosions in an isolated and exposed position.

The Government will continue to express its opposition to nuclear testing in the Pacific and will maintain its support for the conclusion of a treaty which would prohibit the testing of nuclear weapons by all states in all environments.

There is no connection between the continuation of French nuclear testing in the Pacific and the export of Australian uranium to France or the activities of French mining companies in Australia, and retaliatory actions of the kind suggested in the question would not be relevant or effective. Uranium is exported to France pursuant to commercial contracts, and French uranium mining companies operate in Australia in accordance with Government requirements. The supply of uranium to France from Australia has to comply with the provisions of the Australia/France nuclear safeguards agreement, which ensures that the uranium may be used only for peaceful non-military and non-explosive purposes in France's nuclear industry.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

(2) Does the RAS provide financial assistance to people who are highly skilled and who are able to afford the cost of moving; if so, why.

(3) Does the pamphlet explaining and advertising the scheme refer only to the wife of a person eligible for the assistance; if so, does this mean that married women are not eligible for the benefits provided under the scheme if they wish to relocate for employment purposes.

(4) What are the guidelines which determine whether people registered with the local Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) would be capable, after training, of filling any vacancy for which a person seeking relocation to the area has applied.

(5) Is an applicant for the position from outside the area eligible for assistance under the RAS if the training required to make a local unemployed person suitable for the position will take a number of years or is not available in the area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 1,527 people were relocated under the terms of the RAS in the financial year 1980-81.

(2) Yes. The RAS is designed to assist in the placement of people who are already or are about to become unemployed. It is not the Government's policy to apply a means-test to those eligible for assistance under its manpower programmes which are also intended to ensure that skilled labour is available where it is needed.

(3) No. The current pamphlet refers to (a) the spouse and (b) an adult dependant of the applicant and not merely to the wife of an applicant. Married women are not excluded under the Scheme and receive assistance provided they satisfy all the eligibility criteria laid down under RAS.

(4) The acceptability of people registered with the local CES to fill, after training, a vacancy for which a RAS applicant has applied would be determined by whether or not the employer had lodged an on-the-job training vacancy and, if so , whether the CES office in the area judged that a local applicant would be capable of being trained to the level required and would prove satisfactory to the employer.

(5) An applicant for a position from outside the area is eligible for assistance under RAS if he or she has received an offer of suitable continuing employment and the CES office in the area in question judged that there are no local unemployed who are suitable immediately for the position, or would be suitable even after training in the case of an on-the-job training vacancy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details for each State of: (a) the post offices under consideration for closure; (b) post offices under consideration for reduced services; and (c) the 'Other Services' under consideration for reduction or removal for the year 1981-82.
(2) What cash savings are these proposals budgeted to produce.
(3) What is the estimated saving per article.
(4) What is the procedure adopted before any service is reduced.
(5) What input are local users invited or able to contribute before these decisions are implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia Post continually reviews its network of postal facilities and the services provided. New facilities are provided and existing facilities relocated or withdrawn to meet the changing needs of the community served. Broad programmes are developed to vary facilities and services provided but those programmes are under ongoing review and are revised progressively to meet changing local circumstances.
The following details must be considered against that background:

(a) Thirty post offices were withdrawn from service in the period November/ December 1981. For the remainder of 1981-82, some 52 offices are under consideration for withdrawal, with the breakdown, by State, being:
New South Wales-20; Victoria-2; Queensland-6; South Australia-12; Western Australia-11; Tasmania 1.

Particular efforts are directed towards ensuring consultation with local community representatives, including Federal and State Members of Parliament, municipal authorities, progress associations etc., before changes are implemented.

The planning process includes also a review of alternative service facilities which will be available to a community once any change to services or facilities is introduced. In rural areas especially, consultation is even more extensive and, in many cases, individual householders are consulted in advance of any change which could affect the postal services available to them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Ashford Community Hospital in South Australia, which is a non- profit hospital and the first in South Australia to receive accreditation for funding under the previous hospital arrangements, lost the right to admit and treat eligible pensioners and subsequently lost 25 per cent of its income and does it face closure in two months time as a result of the hospital funding and health insurance charges.
(2) Will pensioners using the hospital now have to be admitted to a 'higher cost bed' public hospital instead of in the more convenient and less expensive community hospital.
(3) What action will be taken to ensure the continued viability of the Ashford hospital and other non-profit community hospitals in South Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following the Commonwealth's review of its health funding arrangements in the light of the Report of the Jamison Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, it was decided that section 34 of the Health Insurance Act should be repealed from 1 September 1981.

Under the section 34 arrangements the Commonwealth met the full cost of private hospital treatment to certain patients (eligible pensioners) in private hospitals. The arrangements were limited to nine private hospitals in South Australia, including the Ashford Community Hospital. The arrangements were made to meet a possible demand, after the introduction of Medibank in 1975, by patients seeking full hospital care without charge. This demand did not eventuate and, in fact, available data indicate that there was adequate capacity in the then existing South Australian public hospital system to cope with demand . Notwithstanding this, there has been growth in the number of hospital beds in the public sector since the introduction of the section 34 arrangements. South Australia had 6.9 hospital beds per 1,000 of population in 1980-81 as compared with an Australian average of 6.4 and there were occupancy rates of 69.4 per cent in the public sector and 55.4 per cent in the private sector. These figures indicate that there is substantial unused capacity in hospitals in South Australia.

The South Australian authorities were advised on several occasions from 1977 onwards that the Commonwealth would review the arrangements unless the State accepted that there was a need to supplement its public hospital system with the section 34 beds and agree to cost-share them with the Commonwealth. Since South Australia showed no willingness to confirm that the beds were needed to supplement the public system, the Commonwealth considered that the section 34 arrangements were no longer appropriate.

State governments have the responsibility to manage the total hospital system within their State, including both public and private hospitals. If there is concern about the level of occupancy, and therefore the financial viability, of the Ashford Community Hospital then it would be possible for the South Australian Government to develop co-operative arrangements between public and private hospitals for the provision of services to hospital patients. Such arrangements could be considered for inclusion under the cost-sharing arrangements within the terms of the Commonwealth's no growth policy.

(2) It is a condition of Commonwealth funding to South Australia under the hospital cost-sharing arrangements that eligible pensioners and their dependants , plus those in special need and their dependants, be provided with public hospital treatment and accommodation free of charge. How the State arranges for the provision of such services is one for it to decide.

(3) The new health funding and insurance arrangements have reinforced the Commonwealth's commitment to private hospitals as an essential component of Australia's health care delivery system. The confining of free access to public hospitals to those in genuine need and increased public hospital charges will considerably strengthen the position of private hospitals in the medium to long term. The Commonwealth's decision to continue to pay the $16 bed day subsidy and to increase this to $28 per day for patients receiving prescribed surgical procedures, will also assist the private hospital sector. All private hospitals, including the Ashford Community Hospital, share in the Commonwealth's subsidies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will all cigarettes on the market be tested by the Government before the proposed labelling of tar and nicotine contents is instituted; if not, why not.

(2) Is the Minister for Health aware of current consumer confusion over company labelling of certain products as 'mild' or 'extra mild' when some so labelled do not meet 'low tar' or nicotine requirements; if so, in what way will the new labelling clarify for consumers what they are actually smoking.
(3) Will negotiations with the tobacco industry be reopened in order to ensure that cigarette packets are precisely labelled with tar and nicotine content.
(4) Will an agreement be negotiated which requires labelling with carbon monoxide content, and, as for food products, with the additives used for flavour purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Recently the tobacco manufacturers and importers adopted a voluntary code in respect of corrected particulate matter (sometimes referred to as 'tar') and nicotine labelling on cigarette packaging. Clause 2.3 of the Code states:

'The collaborative test result will be that recorded in the latest (Australian Government Analytical Laboratories) published round of tests and, for the purposes of the initial implementation of the Code, that round of tests contained in the News Release of 11th August, 1980 from the Commonwealth Minister for Health except in those cases where
(a) a brand did not appear in that round of tests or,
(b) the formulation of a brand has been significantly altered since that round of tests.

In the case of brands falling within the exceptions in 2.3(a) or 2.3(b) above the test result will be that recorded by the manufacturer's own laboratory or, alternatively in the case of an imported brand, the laboratory of one of the signatories to the code but such brands will be submitted to the AGAL for confirmatory testing under the current collaborative testing procedures and the result of such collaborative testing will, when known, supersede the result of the individual laboratory test. The result of that individual test will, in the case of a new brand, be notified to the AGAL as soon as distribution of the brand in the market place commences and in all other cases be notified to the AGAL as soon as it is completed.'
In the terms of the code, manufacturers must advise AGAL of their own laboratories' results.

(2) Yes. The Department of Health has been asked to pursue the matter of ' mildness' labelling with the tobacco industry. In the meantime the labelling with tar and nicotine yields will enable smokers to weigh the claims of advertising concerning mildness.
Smokers who consider that they need precise yield details can refer to the ' Smokers' Tar Table' published by the Department of Health.

(3) No. The code provides for a modified form of 'banding' of tar and nicotine yields. It is not proposed at this stage to require yields to be stated more precisely than by the appropriate band, which is quite narrow. The propsed yield labelling is consistent with the technical difficulties that exist and the present limited capacity of AGAL to conduct the collaborative testing program that is involved.

The code is subject to review after two years. Moreover, further reductions of the maximum permitted tar and nicotine levels would be considered in consultation with industry once the code had been in operation for at least twelve months.

(4) Consultations between AGAL and the tobacco industry are continuing on the matter of an agreed uniform testing methodology for ascertaining carbon monoxide yields of cigarettes. It is intended that a pilot study of the testing of carbon monoxide yields will be carried out by AGAL during the first half of 1982, in order to resolve the technical difficulties involved.

Whilst in the terms of the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare entitled-'Drug Problems in Australia-an Intoxicated Society?' only tar and nicotine yields are required to be stated on cigarettes packets, Consideration is being given to the inclusion of carbon monoxide yields as well.

As regards additives used for flavouring of tobacco, I should emphasise that it is well known that there are many complex chemical compounds in tobacco smoke and that very little is known about the potential harmful effects of most of these in humans. It would therefore be difficult to prescribe which components should be specifically tested and labelled on cigarette packets. However, in terms of the need for advice to the consumer on health hazards, this issue should be viewed against the already widely publicised and prominently labelled health warning-'Smoking is a health hazard'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard, page 890) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers to two questions asked last week by Senators Bjelke- Petersen and Townley concerning Zimbabwe and the presence there of North Korean military instructors. As the Australian High Commissioner to Zimbabwe was recently in Canberra reporting to the Minister and he also recently briefed the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on this matter as well as on the biased anti-Zimbabwean Press reports which were being reprinted in the Australian media, will the Minister bring down a statement on current events in Zimbabwe and Southern Africa for the information of honourable senators? Will the Minister not agree that Zimbabwe, a non-aligned country, whose armed forces are currently being predominantly trained by British instructors, is entitled to invite instructors from other countries, including Australia, to train its armed forces?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information in response to the honourable senator's question:

You referred to the military assistance being provided by North Korea to help train the Zimbabwe Army. Senator Guilfoyle confirmed that the Government of Zimbabwe had accepted an offer of assistance from the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, and that this was intended to train and equip a brigade of defence forces of Zimbabwe.

As you quite correctly pointed out, the Zimbabwe armed forces are being predominantly trained by a British Military Training Team, under an arrangement which has operated since Zimbabwe attained independence in April 1980. I agree that it is a decision for Zimbabwe itself whether to invite instructors from other countries to train its armed forces. In announcing its decision to accept the North Korean offer, the Government of Zimbabwe said this was consistent with Zimbabwe's policy of non-alignment. I would repeat Senator Guilfoyle's observation that we hope that North Koreans are approaching their task in the same light. The question of providing Australian military training assistance to Zimbabwe is not under consideration.

The task of restructuring and integrating into one force the three armies which operated in Zimbabwe prior to independence-Mr Mugabe's ZAMLA, Mr Nkomo's ZIPRA and the former Rhodesian security forces-is obviously crucial for the future stability of Zimbabwe, and from the outset Mr Mugabe has accorded it high priority. This task is clearly not an easy one, and it will take some time to achieve complete confidence among three such previously antagonistic groups. However considerable progress has been made to date, and this is a cause for encouragement.

You also asked if I would bring down a statement on current events in Zimbabwe and Southern Africa. I believe the Government's policies towards Southern Africa, and the conduct of its relations with Zimbabwe, are widely known and understood. I do not think it necessary at this particular time to table a statement specifically on current developments in the region. I will, however, keep this under review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2268) Senator MacGibbon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware that AIC Q5- 1981, which prohibits the use of Brisbane Airport between 2100 and 2415 hours eastern standard time, is being abused by the Department of Transport insofar as it demands that aircraft departing Brisbane Airport have to be 90 nautical miles away at 9.00 p.m., which means that they must be taxiing by 8.40 p.m.?
(b) Is the Minister aware that a NOTAM, a notice to airmen, to the effect that Mackay Airport is now to be closed at 8.40 p.m. on a Friday night has been issued?

(c) Why cannot regular public transport jet aircraft operate into those airports where air traffic control staff are not on duty, as they have for years into Gove without any incident whatsoever? How can the Government tolerate a double standard from the Department on this point? Will the Minister , as a matter of urgency, instruct the Department of Transport that it cannot inflict the economic consequences of its mismanagement on the economy of one State of the Commonwealth in isolaton?
(d) How much does the Minister estimate that fares Australia-wide will rise as a result of the lack of use of aircraft coming into these airports because of these limitations?
The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(a) The circular mentioned states that the airspace within 90 nautical miles of Brisbane becomes a temporary restricted area from 9.00 p.m. to midnight daily and that flights within this area will not be permitted except for mercy flights or other emergency operations. The taxi time of 8.40 p.m. is chosen to ensure that any aircraft departing Brisbane is outside the 90 nautical miles position before 9.00 p.m.

(b) The currently published hours of operation of Mackay Tower are: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday 6.15 a.m. to 8.15 p.m.; Friday 6.15 a .m. to 8.30 p.m.; Sunday 6.15 a.m. to 9.30 p.m. (Eastern Standard Time). The only change between these hours and the previously published hours of coverage are to accommodate the changes in airline schedules arising from daylight saving in the southern States. These hours of operation cover all airline scheduled jet services.

(c) In order to meet standards of operational safety appropriate to regular public transport flights by jet aircraft, the provision of controlled airspace and associated air traffic control services is required. In certain areas of relatively low traffic density and in remote locations such as Gove, concessions against these requirements have been granted. However, it is not proposed to extend such concessions against safety standards to those areas where some form of equivalent safety cannot be said to exist compared with the protection afforded by the services of Air Traffic Control.

(d) With the establishment of the Independent Air Fares Committee, I no longer have the responsibility for determining domestic air fares. I would expect that , should additional costs be incurred, the airlines would raise the matter in the context of fares submissions to the Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2266) Senator Crichton- Browne asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned the six Indian castaways on Irvine Island, as well as the general question of coastal surveillance and the entry of illicit drugs into Australia. The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The civil coastal surveillance program co-ordinated by his Department gives coverage to the north western coast of Western Australia in a number of ways.

Light twin aircraft under charter to the Department of Transport patrol the northern littoral daily from Karratha to Cairns, principally for quarantine purposes, including selected tracks through the area in question.
RAAF P3 Orion long range maritime patrol aircraft give radar coverage of the entire 200 nautical mile Australian Fishing Zone two or four times per month; this includes the north-west.
RAN patrol boats pass regularly through the area and are available to intercept and investigate particular sightings reports when requested.

The coastal surveillance program provides for routine patrolling in selected areas with emphasis being programmed according to the priority requirements of Commonwealth Government departments having a major interest in coastal surveillance.

The Government is alert to the need to keep pace with trends in coastal activity and is currently reviewing the civil coastal surveillance program. The Minister for Transport has advised that the circumstances of the unauthorised arrival of the Indian nationals in the area are being investigated by officers of his Department in conjunction with officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
I refer now to that aspect of your question which concerned the entry of illicit drugs into Australia.

My colleague, the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has advised that, insofar as his Department is responsible for policing the entry of illicit drugs into Australia, to be totally effective enormous effort and virtually unlimited resources would need to be applied to the surveillance function.

The Minister has advised that the provision of resources of this magnitude would involve considerable economic and physical practicabilities. However, within the resources available he does consider that materially effective use is being made of those resources for the detection of illegal immigrants, quarantine risks and illicit narcotic importations.
The effectiveness of coastal surveillance has recently been re-considered by the Government and steps are being taken to even further enhance the surveillance activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2500) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice concerning the operation of tourist passenger trains in Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following additional information to the honourable senator's question:

In addition to correspondence with the Australian National Railways Commission , I have received representations on a number of occasions concerning a proposal to operate a tourist passenger train in Tasmania between Launceston and Hobart. The proposal has been examined by the Commission which advised that the operation of tourist services cannot be considered at least until after the completion of the Tasmanian rail track rehabilitation program.

I have considerable sympathy with regard to the effect that this may have on the viability of such proposals but I regret that it does not seem possible for the Commission to consider any proposal at present, given the current state of track in Tasmania. In this regard, the Commission has advised that the track is only suitable for freight operations at present and it is expected that these operations will increase in future.
These services are subject to an overall speed limit of 55 kph, with many sections being restricted to 35 kph.

To date, a total of 19.62 kilometres of the track between Launceston and Hobart has been upgraded in areas where such work was considered necessary to continue operations and a further 50.72 kilometres is planned for upgrading under the Commonwealth-funded program by 1985.

In the final event, the question of operating a tourist passenger train must be one for the commercial and technical judgment of the Commission. However, I am sure the Commission will be in a position to review such proposals once rehabilitation of the railway line between Launceston and Hobart has been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 February, 1982 (Hansard, page 80) Senator Kilgariff asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the high regard which Australia is accorded in the Middle East and in particular to the fact that that regard is not at all enhanced by the dilapidated condition of the Australian Embassy in Cairo. Will the Minister advise what action has been taken to improve accommodation conditions of the Australian contingent in Cairo ? I understand that modern accommodation is to become available in the area and I ask whether the Government has considered acquiring a lease to protect Australian accommodation in the future.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I should like to take this opportunity to record that I wrote to the Minister for Administrative Services on the matter as responsibility for the provision of office accommodation overseas is vested in the Minister, and I wrote to the Ministers for Trade and Resources and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs as their Departments are represented in Cairo.

My approach to the Minister for Administrative Services was essentially to seek his support in seeking supplementary funds out of additional estimates to permit a lease to proceed in Cairo and I have since been advised that the Minister has asked for a report on the matter and will contact me as soon as it is available.
